meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to provide for the regulation of activities or matters relating to Chinese medicines, including the registration of practitioners of Chinese medicine, the licensing of traders in Chinese medicines, the registration of proprietary Chinese medicines and the manufacture, possession and sale of Chinese medicines. (Amended 16 of 2018 s. 3)

part.name: P1
part.heading: Preliminary

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Chinese Medicine Ordinance.

This Ordinance shall come into operation on a day to be appointed by the Secretary for Health by notice in the Gazette, and different days may be so appointed for different provisions. (Amended L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; L.N. 144 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 121)
subsection.def: active ingredient (有效成分) in relation to a proprietary Chinese medicine, means a substance or compound that is used or is intended to be used in the manufacture of the proprietary Chinese medicine and that contributes to the pharmacological effect or effects of the proprietary Chinese medicine;

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in relation to a proprietary Chinese medicine, means a certificate issued under section 121;

subsection.def: Chairman (管委會主席) means the Chairman of the Council and includes any person elected to act as temporary Chairman at any meeting of the Council in accordance with the standing orders made under section 49;
Chinese herbal medicine (中藥材) means any of the substances specified in Schedule 1 or 2;
Chinese Medicines Committee (中藥管理小組) means the committee established under section 25(1)(b)(i);
Chinese Medicines Traders Committee (中藥業管理小組) means the committee established under section 25(1)(b)(ii);
Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners (紀律小組) means the committee established under section 25(1)(a)(iii);

dispense (配發) means the preparation and supply of Chinese herbal medicines on or in accordance with a prescription given by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, a listed Chinese medicine practitioner or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of section 90(7), and dispensing (配發) and dispenser (配劑員) shall be construed accordingly;
domestic premises (住用處所) means any premises which are constructed or intended to be used for habitation;
due inquiry (適當的研訊) means an inquiry by the Practitioners Board conducted substantially in accordance with the prescribed procedure;
Examination Committee (考試小組) means the committee established under section 25(1)(a)(ii);
functions (職能) includes duties and powers;
label (標籤) includes any statement forming part of or affixed to the container or package of Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines;
Licensing Examination (執業資格試) means the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Licensing Examination set and conducted by the Practitioners Board under section 59;
limited registration (有限制註冊) means registration under section 85;
listed Chinese medicine practitioner (表列中醫) means a Chinese medicine practitioner whose name is entered on the list maintained by the Practitioners Board under section 90;

manufacture (製造) in relation to a proprietary Chinese medicine, means the preparation, production, packing or re-packing of the proprietary Chinese medicine for sale or distribution, and manufacturer (製造商) shall be construed accordingly;
manufacturer licence (製造商牌照) means a licence issued under section 132;
Medicines Board (中藥組) means the Chinese Medicines Board established under section 12(b);

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: means any box, packet or other article in which any proprietary Chinese medicine is enclosed; and

paragraph.name: b

subsection.def: package insert (說明書) means any leaflet, notification or other written material supplied with the package of a proprietary Chinese medicine to provide information in respect of the proprietary Chinese medicine, but does not include a label;
practising certificate (執業證明書) means a certificate issued under section 76;

def.name: PractisingChineseMedicine
def.leadIn: practising Chinese medicine (作中醫執業、以中醫方式行醫) means any of the following act or activities—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the diagnosis, treatment, prevention or alleviation of any disease or any symptom of a disease;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prescription of Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the regulation of the functional states of the human body,

def.continued: on the basis of traditional Chinese medicine in general practice, acupuncture or bone-setting, and Chinese medicine practice or practice of Chinese medicine (中醫執業) shall be construed accordingly;

subsection.def: Practitioners Board (中醫組) means the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board established under section 12(a);

def.name: Process,Processing
def.leadIn: process or processing (炮製) means any type of treatment or preparation applied to a Chinese herbal medicine or mixture of Chinese herbal medicines based on traditional Chinese medicine before it is being—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: offered for sale;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: supplied to a patient; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: used for the manufacture of a proprietary Chinese medicine;

def.name: ProprietaryChineseMedicine
def.leadIn: proprietary Chinese medicine (中成藥) means any proprietary product—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: composed solely of the following as active ingredients—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any Chinese herbal medicines; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any materials of herbal, animal or mineral origin customarily used by the Chinese; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any medicines and materials referred to in subparagraphs (i) and (ii) respectively;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: formulated in a finished dose form; and

paragraph.name: c

def.name: RegisteredChineseMedicinePractitioner
def.leadIn: registered Chinese medicine practitioner (註冊中醫)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: means a person whose name appears on the Register and who is registered under section 69 or 85;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: excludes a person whose name is entered on the list maintained by the Practitioners Board under section 90;

subsection.def: registered particulars (註冊詳情) means the particulars of a proprietary Chinese medicine required under section 121(1)(b);
registration assessment (註冊審核) means the assessment conducted by the Practitioners Board under section 94;
Registration Committee (註冊事務小組) means the committee established under section 25(1)(a)(i);
Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders (中藥業監管小組) means the committee established under section 25(1)(b)(iii);
retail or retailing (零售) means the selling of any Chinese herbal medicines to a person who obtains the same other than for the purpose of wholesale, and retailer (零售商) shall be construed accordingly;
retailer licence (零售商牌照) means a licence issued under section 114;
Secretary (局長) means the Secretary for Health; (Amended L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; L.N. 144 of 2022)

def.name: Sell

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: offer or expose for sale;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: supply without payment; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: offer or expose for supply without payment,

def.continued: and sale (銷售) and seller (銷售商) shall be construed accordingly;

subsection.def: trade of Chinese medicines (中藥業) means the carrying out of business in the dispensing, retailing, wholesale dealing, manufacturing, importing, or processing of any Chinese herbal medicine or proprietary Chinese medicine, as the case may be, and Chinese medicines trader (中藥業者) shall be construed accordingly;

def.name: Wholesale,WholesaleDealing
def.leadIn: wholesale (批發) or wholesale dealing (批發交易) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the importing and selling; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the obtaining and selling,

def.continued: of any Chinese herbal medicine or proprietary Chinese medicine to—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a manufacturer; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.leadIn: a person who obtains such medicine for the purpose of—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: selling again; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: supplying or causing to supply,

paragraph.continued: such medicine to a third party in the course of business or activity carried out by that person,

def.continued: and wholesaler and wholesale dealer (批發商) shall be construed accordingly;

subsection.def: wholesaler licence in proprietary Chinese medicines (中成藥批發商牌照) means a licence issued under section 135.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 98(5)(b) and 104(4) and (5), an appeal to the Court of Appeal shall be deemed to be finally determined when the earliest of the following events occurs, whichever is applicable in the circumstances—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the appeal to the Court of Appeal is withdrawn or abandoned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when the specified period expires without an application for leave to appeal having been made to the Court of Appeal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if, before the expiry of the specified period, an application for leave to appeal is made to the Court of Appeal—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: when the application is withdrawn or abandoned;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the application is refused, when the specified period expires without an application for leave to appeal having been made to the Court of Final Appeal; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the application is granted, when the appeal to the Court of Final Appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or disposed of; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if, before the expiry of the specified period, an application for leave to appeal is made to the Court of Final Appeal—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: when the application is withdrawn, abandoned or refused; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the application is granted, when the appeal to the Court of Final Appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or disposed of. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 121)

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (2)—
subsection.def: application for leave to appeal (上訴許可申請) means an application made to the Court of Appeal or the Court of Final Appeal under section 24 of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) for leave to appeal to the Court of Final Appeal from a judgment of the Court of Appeal;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of an application for leave to appeal made to the Court of Appeal, means—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subject to subparagraph (ii), the period of 28 days within which the notice of motion referred to in section 24(2) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) is required to be filed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if, on an application made within the 28-day period referred to in subparagraph (i), the Court of Appeal extends that period, the period as so extended; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of an application for leave to appeal made to the Court of Final Appeal, means—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subject to subparagraph (ii), the period of 28 days within which the notice of motion referred to in section 24(4) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) is required to be filed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if, on an application made within the 28-day period referred to in subparagraph (i), the Court of Final Appeal extends that period, the period as so extended. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 121)

part.name: P2
part.heading: The Chinese Medicine Council of Hong Kong

section.name: s3
section.heading: Establishment of Council
section.content: There is established a council called the Chinese Medicine Council of Hong Kong.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Composition of Council
section.leadIn: The Council shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director who shall be an ex officio member; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following 18 members, each of whom shall be appointed by the Chief Executive—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a Chairman;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 2 public officers;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 5 Chinese medicine practitioners;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: 5 persons from the trade of Chinese medicines;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: 2 persons from educational or scientific research institutions in Hong Kong; and

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: 3 lay persons.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3) and section 7, a member of the Council appointed under section 4(b) shall hold office for such period not exceeding 3 years as may be specified in the letter of his appointment.
A member may, upon the expiry of his term of office, be reappointed.

subsection.leadIn: A member appointed under section 4(b) or reappointed under subsection (2) may, at any time before the expiry of his term of office, resign his office by giving notice in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a member other than the Chairman, to the Chairman;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of the Chairman, to the Chief Executive.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Replacement members
section.content: Where, before the expiry of his term of office, a member of the Council appointed under section 4(b) resigns or his office becomes vacant, the Chief Executive may appoint a person who is suitably qualified for appointment under section 4(b) to hold office in place of that member until the expiry of the period for which he was appointed.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Vacation of office
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a member of the Council—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is sentenced to imprisonment, whether suspended or not, for any offence by any court or magistrate in Hong Kong or elsewhere;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is the subject of an order made under section 98; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: becomes bankrupt or enters into a voluntary arrangement with his creditors within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Chief Executive—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is satisfied that a member of the Council is no longer ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is of the opinion that a member of the Council is unable or unfit to perform his duties and exercise his powers as a member of the Council,

section.continued: the Chief Executive may declare his office as a member of the Council to be vacant, and shall notify the fact in such manner as the Chief Executive thinks fit; and upon such declaration the office shall become vacant.

subsection.content: If a member of the Council appointed under section 4(b) is, because of illness or any other reasons, unable to perform his duties and exercise his powers as a member of the Council for any period, the Chief Executive may appoint another person who is suitably qualified for appointment under section 4(b), not being one whose office has been declared vacant under section 7 or who is disqualified from holding office under section 9, to be a temporary member of the Council in place of the member during that period.
While any person is acting as a temporary member of the Council, he shall be capable of performing all the duties and of executing all the powers of the member whom he is temporarily replacing.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Disqualification
section.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against whom an order under section 98 has at any time been made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: who is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: undergoing a sentence of imprisonment;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an undischarged bankrupt;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: not ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whom the Chief Executive considers unfit for appointment,

section.continued: shall not be eligible for appointment or reappointment, as the case may be, as a member of the Council.

subsection.leadIn: The Council shall have—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Council secretary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a legal adviser who shall be a solicitor or counsel.

subsection.content: The persons specified in subsection (1)(a) and (b) shall be appointed by the Secretary.

subsection.leadIn: The functions of the Council shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to ensure adequate standards of professional practice and professional conduct in the profession of Chinese medicine practitioners;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to promote professional education of Chinese medicine practitioners;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to ensure adequate standards of practice and conduct in the trade of Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: to promote and ensure—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the proper use of Chinese herbal medicines;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the safety, quality and efficacy of proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to co-ordinate and supervise the activities of the boards; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1)(e), the Council shall co-ordinate and supervise the activities of the boards by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: determining the policies to be implemented by the boards;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: examining policy matters in relation to the activities of the boards;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: examining any proposals, recommendations and reports from the boards regarding the activities of the boards or the implementation of policies and directing the boards to amend any of such proposals or recommendations as it thinks fit;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: directing the boards to implement such policies and activities as it thinks fit;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: handling appeals against decisions of the boards as provided for under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: providing any advice and assistance as may be required by the boards; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: exercising its powers under this Ordinance in such manner as it considers most conducive to the satisfactory performance by each board of the board’s functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.def: In this section, boards (各組) means the Practitioners Board and the Medicines Board.

part.name: P3
part.heading: The Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board and the Chinese Medicines Board

section.name: s12
section.heading: Establishment of boards
section.leadIn: There are established—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chinese Medicines Board.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Composition of Practitioners Board
section.leadIn: The Practitioners Board shall consist of the following members, each of whom shall be appointed by the Secretary—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Council;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 2 public officers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 6 Chinese medicine practitioners, 2 of whom shall be members of the Council;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: 1 person from the trade of Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: 1 person from an educational or scientific research institution in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: 3 lay persons.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Composition of Medicines Board
section.leadIn: The Medicines Board shall consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director who shall be the chairman; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following persons, each of whom shall be appointed by the Secretary—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 2 public officers;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 5 persons from the trade of Chinese medicines, 2 of whom shall be members of the Council;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 2 Chinese medicine practitioners;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: 1 person from an educational or scientific research institution in Hong Kong; and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: 3 lay persons.

subsection.content: Subject to sections 13 and 14, the Secretary may appoint members of the Council, and persons who are not such members, to be members of the Practitioners Board and the Medicines Board.
Unless a contrary intention appears in the context, a reference to a member of a board includes a reference to the chairman of the board.

Subject to subsections (3) and (4) and section 18, a member of the Practitioners Board appointed under section 13 and a member of the Medicines Board appointed under section 14(b), as the case may be, shall hold office for such period not exceeding 3 years as may be specified in the letter of his appointment.
A member of a board may, upon the expiry of his term of office, be reappointed.

subsection.leadIn: A member of the Practitioners Board appointed under section 13 or reappointed under subsection (2) may, at any time before the expiry of his term of office, resign his office by giving notice in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a member other than the chairman, to the chairman;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of the chairman, to the Secretary.

subsection.content: A member of the Medicines Board appointed under section 14(b) or reappointed under subsection (2) may, at any time before the expiry of his term of office, resign his office by giving notice in writing to the chairman.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Replacement members
section.content: Where, before the expiry of his term of office, a member of a board resigns or his office becomes vacant, the Secretary may appoint a person who is suitably qualified for appointment to hold office in place of that member until the expiry of the period for which he was appointed.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Vacation of office
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a member of a board—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is sentenced to imprisonment, whether suspended or not, for any offence by any court or magistrate in Hong Kong or elsewhere;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is the subject of an order made under section 98; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: becomes bankrupt or enters into a voluntary arrangement with his creditors within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Secretary—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is satisfied that a member of a board is no longer ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is of the opinion that a member of a board is unable or unfit to perform his duties and exercise his powers as a member of the board,

section.continued: the Secretary may declare his office as a member of the board to be vacant, and shall notify the fact in such manner as the Secretary thinks fit; and upon such declaration the office shall become vacant.

subsection.content: If a member of a board is, because of illness or any other reasons, unable to perform his duties and exercise his powers as such member for any period, the Secretary may appoint another person suitably qualified for appointment to such membership to be a temporary member in place of the member during that period.
While any person is acting as a temporary member of a board, he shall be capable of performing all the duties and of executing all the powers of the member whom he is temporarily replacing.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Disqualification
section.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against whom an order under section 98 has at any time been made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: who is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: undergoing a sentence of imprisonment;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an undischarged bankrupt;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: not ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whom the Secretary considers unfit for appointment,

section.continued: shall not be eligible for appointment or reappointment, as the case may be, as a member of a board.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Cessation of membership
section.content: If during the period of his office, a member of a board who is not a member of the Council when appointed, becomes a member of the Council, he ceases to be a member of the board.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Continuation of membership
section.leadIn: If during the period when the Practitioners Board or the Medicines Board, as the case may be, is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: considering a complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: considering any information;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: conducting an inquiry; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: conducting a review,

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: gives a notice of resignation; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: ceases to be a member by reason of the expiry of his term of office or other circumstances referred to in section 21,

section.continued: the member may continue to be a member of that board for the purpose of completing the performance of his function in respect of paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d), as the case may be.

subsection.leadIn: On each board, there shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a board secretary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a legal adviser who shall be a solicitor or counsel.

subsection.content: The persons specified in subsection (1)(a) and (b) shall be appointed by the Secretary.
The functions of the Practitioners Board and the Medicines Board are set out in Parts I and II of Schedule 3 respectively.
The Secretary may, after consultation with the Council, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 3.

part.name: P4
part.heading: Committees of the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board and the Chinese Medicines Board

section.name: s25
section.heading: Committees of boards to be set up

subsection.leadIn: The Council shall establish—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: under the Practitioners Board, the following committees—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Registration Committee;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Examination Committee; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: under the Medicines Board, the following committees—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Chinese Medicines Committee;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Chinese Medicines Traders Committee; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders,

subsection.continued: and these committees shall have the functions specified in Parts I, II, III, IV, V and VI of Schedule 4 respectively.

subsection.content: The Secretary may, after consultation with the Council, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 4.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Registration Committee
section.leadIn: The Registration Committee shall consist of the following members, each of whom shall be nominated by the Practitioners Board and appointed by the Council—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Practitioners Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 5 Chinese medicine practitioners; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 1 person from an educational or scientific research institution in Hong Kong.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Examination Committee
section.leadIn: The Examination Committee shall consist of the following members, each of whom shall be nominated by the Practitioners Board and appointed by the Council—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Practitioners Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 4 Chinese medicine practitioners; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 2 persons from educational or scientific research institutions in Hong Kong.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners
section.leadIn: The Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners shall consist of the following members, each of whom shall be nominated by the Practitioners Board and appointed by the Council—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Practitioners Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a deputy chairman who shall be a member of the Practitioners Board;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 4 Chinese medicine practitioners; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: 2 persons who shall be lay members of the Practitioners Board.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Chinese Medicines Committee
section.leadIn: The Chinese Medicines Committee shall consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 1 public officer who shall be appointed by the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Government Chemist or his representative; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the following persons, each of whom shall be nominated by the Medicines Board and appointed by the Council—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 2 persons from the trade of Chinese medicines;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 1 Chinese medicine practitioner; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: 1 person from an educational or scientific research institution in Hong Kong.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Chinese Medicines Traders Committee
section.leadIn: The Chinese Medicines Traders Committee shall consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 2 public officers who shall be appointed by the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following persons, each of whom shall be nominated by the Medicines Board and appointed by the Council—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 2 persons from the trade of Chinese medicines;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 1 Chinese medicine practitioner; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: 1 lay person.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders
section.leadIn: The Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders shall consist of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 1 public officer who shall be appointed by the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the following persons, each of whom shall be nominated by the Medicines Board and appointed by the Council—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a chairman who shall be a member of the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a deputy chairman who shall be a member of the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 2 persons from the trade of Chinese medicines;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: 1 Chinese medicine practitioner; and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: 2 persons who shall be lay members of the Medicines Board.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Provisions applicable to Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners and Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders

subsection.leadIn: If during the period when the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners or the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders, as the case may be, is considering any complaint or information, a member of the committee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: gives a notice of resignation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ceases to be a member by reason of the expiry of his term of office or other circumstances referred to in section 38,

subsection.continued: the member may continue to be a member of that committee for the purpose of completing the performance of his function in respect of that complaint or information.

subsection.content: At a meeting of the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners or the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders, as the case may be, the chairman or, in his absence, the deputy chairman, shall preside.

Notwithstanding subsection (2), if both the chairman and the deputy chairman declare their interest in respect of a particular case which is to be considered at a meeting, neither of them may preside or sit at the meeting and the members present (including the chairman and the deputy chairman) shall elect another member to preside at the meeting.
The quorum of a meeting is 3, subject to 1 of whom being a lay member.

subsection.leadIn: In considering a case which has been brought to the attention of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners for considering whether the Practitioners Board should be recommended to hold an inquiry; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders for making suitable recommendations to the Medicines Board,

subsection.continued: both committees shall act in accordance with the prescribed procedure.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners or the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders, as the case may be, is considering any complaint or information received in respect of a particular case and a member of the committee is subject of such complaint or information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the member shall not take part in the consideration of such complaint or information or attend any meeting held for such purposes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Council shall at the same time appoint a temporary member; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the committee shall consider the complaint or information afresh.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Terms of appointment to committees under this Part

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), a member appointed under this Part shall hold office for such period not exceeding 3 years as may be specified in the letter of his appointment.
The member may, upon the expiry of his term of office, be reappointed.

subsection.leadIn: A member appointed or reappointed under this Part may, at any time before the expiry of his term of office, resign his office by giving notice in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a member other than the chairman of a committee, to the chairman of the committee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of the chairman of a committee, to the Council.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Replacement members
section.content: Where, before the expiry of his term of office, a member of a committee under this Part resigns or his office becomes vacant, the Council may appoint a person who is suitably qualified for appointment to hold office in place of that member until the expiry of the period for which he was appointed.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Vacation of office
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a member of a committee under this Part—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is sentenced to imprisonment, whether suspended or not, for any offence by any court or magistrate in Hong Kong or elsewhere;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is the subject of an order made under section 98; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: becomes bankrupt or enters into a voluntary arrangement with his creditors within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Council—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is satisfied that a member of a committee under this Part is no longer ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is of the opinion that a member of a committee under this Part is unable or unfit to perform his duties and exercise his powers as a member of the committee,

section.continued: the Council may declare his office as a member of the committee to be vacant, and shall notify the fact in such manner as the Council thinks fit; and upon such declaration the office shall become vacant.

subsection.content: If a member of a committee under this Part is for any reason unable to perform his duties and exercise his powers as such member for any period, the Council may appoint another person suitably qualified for appointment to be a temporary member in place of the member during that period.

While any person is acting as a temporary member after appointment to such membership under subsection (1), he shall be capable of performing all the duties and of executing all the powers of the member whom he is temporarily replacing.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Disqualification
section.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against whom an order under section 98 has at any time been made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: who is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: undergoing a sentence of imprisonment;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an undischarged bankrupt;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: not ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whom the Council considers unfit for appointment,

section.continued: shall not be eligible for appointment or reappointment, as the case may be, as a member of a committee under this Part.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Cessation of membership
section.content: If during the period of his office, a member of a committee under this Part who is not a member of a board when appointed under section 26, 27, 28, 29, 30 or 31, as the case may be, becomes a member of a board, he ceases to be a member of that committee.

part.name: P5
part.heading: Miscellaneous Committees

section.name: s39
section.heading: Establishment of committees
section.leadIn: In addition to the power to establish committees under section 25, the Council may, upon the recommendation of the Practitioners Board or the Medicines Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: establish a committee or committees of the board for the purposes of performing such functions as may be prescribed by the Council; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vary, modify or extend the functions of such committee or committees.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2) and section 41, the Council may appoint members of the boards, and persons who are not such members, to be members of a committee.
The Council shall not appoint to any committee a person against whom an order under section 98 has at any time been made.
A member appointed to a committee may, at any time before the expiry of his term of office, resign his office by giving notice in writing to the Council.
Subject to subsection (2), the Council may appoint a person to be the chairman of a committee.
Only a member of a board is eligible to be appointed as the chairman of a committee.
Unless a contrary intention appears in the context, a reference to a member of a committee includes a reference to the chairman of the committee.
A committee may have a legal adviser who shall be a solicitor or counsel.
A legal adviser shall be appointed by the Secretary.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Dissolution of committees
section.content: The Council may, at any time, upon the recommendation of a board, dissolve a committee of the board established under section 39.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Application of provisions
section.content: Unless a contrary intention appears in the context, sections 40, 41 and 42 shall apply to a committee established under section 25 as they apply to a committee established under section 39.

part.name: P6
part.heading: Meetings

subsection.content: The Council, a board or committee shall meet at such times and such places as the Chairman or the chairmen of the respective boards or committees may appoint.

The Chairman or the chairman of a board or committee shall, on a requisition signed by not less than such number of members being a number forming the quorum of the Council, board or committee, as the case may be, summon a meeting of the Council, board or committee, as the case may be, and appoint the time and place for the meeting.
Notwithstanding subsection (1), the Council shall meet at least once every 6 months and as often as may be necessary to transact its business.

The validity of any proceedings of the Council, a board or committee shall not be affected by any defect in the appointment of any member of the Council, board or committee or by any vacancy among the members of the Council, board or committee, as the case may be.

Notwithstanding subsection (1), where there is any defect in the appointment of any member of the Council, a board or committee, it shall constitute the special circumstances referred to in sections 97 and 103 for the purposes of determining the time for appeal.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Questions to be decided by majority
section.content: All questions coming or arising before the Council, a board or committee shall be decided by a majority of votes of members present at a meeting and voting thereon, and in the case of an equality of votes, the Chairman or the chairman of the board or committee shall have a casting vote in addition to his original vote.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Transaction of business by circulation of papers
section.content: Subject to any standing orders made under section 49(a), the Council, a board or committee may transact any of its business by circulation of papers, and a resolution in writing which is signed by all the members of the Council, board or committee for the time being present in Hong Kong (being not less than the number required to constitute a majority of the Council, board or committee, as the case may be,) shall be as valid and effectual as if it had been passed at a meeting by the votes of the members so signing.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Standing orders relating to meetings
section.leadIn: The Council, a board or committee may, subject to this Ordinance, make standing orders—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: governing its procedure in the transaction of business, including, but not limited to, the transaction of business by circulation of papers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regulating the procedure at, and in connection with its meetings including the election of a temporary chairman at a meeting and the casting of votes for the determination of any questions coming or arising before its meeting;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specifying the circumstances under which invitees may attend or make representations at its meetings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: governing the declaration of interest by its chairman and members.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Application of Part VII of Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance
section.content: For the avoidance of doubt, Part VII of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) applies to the Council, a board or committee and appointments to the Council, board or committee except in so far as it is inconsistent with this Ordinance.

part.name: P7
part.heading: Registration of Chinese Medicine Practitioners

section.name: s51
section.heading: Registrar
section.content: For the purpose of this Ordinance, there shall be a Registrar of Chinese Medicine Practitioners who shall be the Director or his designated representative.

subsection.content: The Registrar shall cause a register, to be called the Register of Chinese Medicine Practitioners, to be kept in such form as he may determine, containing the names, addresses and qualifications and such other particulars of all persons who are registered under section 69 or 85 as the Registrar considers appropriate.
The Registrar may maintain separate parts under the Register in respect of persons registered under section 69 or 85.
The Registrar is responsible for the maintenance and custody of the Register.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Publication of Register and evidence of registration, etc.

subsection.content: The Registrar shall publish in the Gazette once every 12 months a list of the names, addresses and qualifications of all persons whose names appear in the Register in such manner as the Registrar may determine.
The publication of the list referred to in subsection (1) shall be prima facie evidence that each person named in the list is registered.

A certificate under the hand of the Registrar stating that the name of a person is at any date or was at any date registered in the Register shall be conclusive evidence in all courts of law of the facts stated in such certificate.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Alterations to Register
section.content: The Registrar may, upon application by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, amend any entry in the Register as to the address or qualifications of or any other particulars relating to the registered Chinese medicine practitioner, if he is satisfied that such amendment is necessary for the purposes of maintaining the accuracy of the Register.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Powers of Practitioners Board to direct or order alterations to Register
section.content: If, in the exercise of its powers under the Ordinance, the Practitioners Board directs or orders that any alterations be made to the Register, the Registrar shall make such alterations as directed or ordered.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Powers of Practitioners Board to order removal of names from Register

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may order the removal from the Register the name of any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has requested in writing that his name be removed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is deceased;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by reason of health, in its opinion, is unfit to practise Chinese medicine;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: being a person required to be the holder of a practising certificate under section 76, has not obtained such a certificate for a period exceeding 6 months since he was first registered under this Ordinance or since the expiry of a practising certificate issued to him under section 76;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: is subject of an order made under section 98(3)(a) or (b).

subsection.content: The Practitioners Board may also order the removal from the Register the name of any person who fails to acknowledge within 4 months after the date of despatch the receipt of a registered letter addressed to him at his address as recorded in the Register, or the last address supplied by him to the Registrar.

For the purpose of subsection (1)(c), the Practitioners Board may make recommendations to the Council to set up a committee under section 39 to assess the fitness or otherwise of any registered Chinese medicine practitioner before an order is made pursuant to that subsection.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Service of notice and order of removal from Register

subsection.content: Where the Practitioners Board intends to order the removal from the Register the name of a Chinese medicine practitioner under section 56(1)(c) or (d) or (2), it shall serve a notice on the Chinese medicine practitioner stating the reasons for its intention to make the order and inviting him to give any written representations to the Practitioners Board.
Where an order is made under section 56(1)(c) or (d) or (2), the Registrar shall serve a copy of the order on the Chinese medicine practitioner concerned.
Any person whose name has been removed under the provisions of this Ordinance from the Register may apply to the Practitioners Board for the restoration of his name to the Register.
An application under subsection (1) shall be made in such form and accompanied by such documents and particulars as the Practitioners Board may determine.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (2), the Practitioners Board may request an applicant to submit a declaration as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: whether he has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment since his name—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: was first entered on the Register; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: was removed from the Register;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: whether he has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect since his name—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: was first entered on the Register; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: was removed from the Register;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of his having been so convicted or having been so found guilty of misconduct, the place and nature of each such offence or record of misconduct, as the case may be;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether there are outstanding legal proceedings against him at the time of the application.

subsection.content: In considering an application for restoration, the Practitioners Board may, in its absolute discretion and after such inquiry as may be necessary, either allow or refuse the application.

subsection.leadIn: If the Practitioners Board allows an application, it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall direct the Registrar, on payment of a prescribed fee by the applicant, to restore the name of the applicant to the Register and the Registrar shall restore the name as directed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may determine that the restoration is subject to such conditions as it considers desirable.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Practitioners Board to set and conduct Licensing Examination

subsection.content: The Practitioners Board shall set and conduct an examination, called the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Licensing Examination, the passing of which shall qualify a person under section 67(a) to apply to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner in Hong Kong.

Without prejudice to section 61, the Practitioners Board may impose such conditions as it thinks fit, being conditions which are relevant to the assessment or improvement of a person’s professional knowledge and practice in Chinese medicine and which a person must comply with before the Practitioners Board allows him to undertake the Licensing Examination.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Practitioners Board to determine syllabus, etc.

subsection.content: The Practitioners Board shall determine the examination syllabus, format, standard of assessment and other related matters in respect of the Licensing Examination.
Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1), the Practitioners Board may appoint examiners for the purposes of the Licensing Examination.

subsection.leadIn: A person shall be eligible to undertake the Licensing Examination if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he satisfies the Practitioners Board that at the time of the application he has satisfactorily completed such undergraduate degree course of training in Chinese medicine practice or its equivalent as is approved by the Practitioners Board; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he is a person whose name is entered on the list maintained under section 90 and is required to undertake the Licensing Examination under section 95.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who seeks to undertake the Licensing Examination under subsection (1)(a) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an application to the Practitioners Board in such form as may be determined by the Practitioners Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pay a prescribed application fee.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Notification and review, etc. of results of Licensing Examination

subsection.content: Where a Licensing Examination is conducted under section 59, the Practitioners Board shall notify the person who undertook the Examination in writing of the relevant result.

Within 14 days of the receipt of the written notification made in accordance with subsection (1), the person may request, in writing stating the reasons relied upon, the Practitioners Board to review the result of the Licensing Examination, to which the written notification relates.

Upon receipt of a request for review under subsection (2) and payment of a prescribed review fee, the Practitioners Board shall review the result and notify the person in writing of its decision within 1 month after the completion of the review.
The Practitioners Board shall conduct and complete any such review as soon as practicable.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Certificate of passing Licensing Examination
section.content: The Practitioners Board shall issue a certificate to a person who has passed the Licensing Examination.

subsection.content: The Practitioners Board may restrict the number of consecutive attempts which a person may make in respect of the Licensing Examination.
The Practitioners Board shall publish such number of consecutive attempts referred to in subsection (1) as it may determine by notice in the Gazette.
For the avoidance of doubt, the notice published under subsection (2) is not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Fees payable in respect of Licensing Examination

subsection.content: Any person who undertakes the Licensing Examination shall pay a prescribed fee before he may take the Examination.
Different fees shall be payable in respect of different parts of the Licensing Examination, where applicable.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Review of decision in relation to Licensing Examination

subsection.content: Where the powers under sections 59(2), 61(1)(a) and 63 have been delegated to the Examination Committee pursuant to section 157, any person aggrieved by its decision made in pursuance of the powers conferred on it may request the Practitioners Board to review the decision of the Examination Committee.

A request for a review under subsection (1) shall be in writing stating the reasons relied upon and shall be made to the Practitioners Board within 14 days of the receipt of the notification of the decision of the Examination Committee.
Upon receipt of the request, the Practitioners Board shall review the decision of the Examination Committee, and shall notify the person concerned of its decision in writing.
A review under this section shall be conducted in accordance with the prescribed procedure.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Qualifications for registration under section 69
section.leadIn: A person is qualified to apply to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner under section 69 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he has passed the Licensing Examination; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Practitioners Board has determined that he is so qualified under section 92.

subsection.content: Any person qualified to apply to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner may apply to the Practitioners Board within such period of time as may be determined by the Practitioners Board.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1) shall be accompanied by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such documents and particulars as may be determined by the Practitioners Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prescribed application fee.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (2)(a), the Practitioners Board may require a person who applies for registration to submit with his application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a declaration as to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether he has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment; and if he has been so convicted, the place and nature of each such offence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether he has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect; and if he has been so found guilty, the place and nature of each such record of misconduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of section 67(b), such evidence from the person regarding his claim of experience, qualifications, knowledge or skill in the practice of Chinese medicine as the Practitioners Board considers appropriate.

subsection.content: The Practitioners Board may require an applicant to submit such further information or particulars as the Practitioners Board considers necessary to enable it to determine the application for registration.

The Practitioners Board may, subject to sections 70 and 71 and the recommendation of the Registration Committee, approve an application for registration as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner under section 68.

Upon approving an application for registration by a person who has been exempted from the Licensing Examination under section 93, the Practitioners Board may impose such conditions and restrictions on the practice of that person as it considers necessary.
Where the Practitioners Board has imposed conditions or restrictions under subsection (2), it may amend, vary or revoke any of such conditions or restrictions.
Upon approving an application for registration under subsection (1), the Practitioners Board shall direct the Registrar to enter the name of the person on the Register.

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may, subject to section 71, refuse to approve the application of a person for registration if it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after due inquiry, that the person has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after due inquiry, that the person has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the person is not qualified to be registered; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that the person has sought to obtain registration by fraud or misrepresentation.

subsection.content: Where the Practitioners Board refuses an application, the Secretary of the Practitioners Board shall notify the applicant in writing of the decision and the reasons of refusal.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Cases involving previous conviction and professional misconduct

subsection.content: If a person who applies under section 68(1) has declared that he has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of an offence punishable with imprisonment or that he has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect, the Practitioners Board shall refer his case to the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners.

Where, pursuant to the consideration and recommendation by the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners, the Practitioners Board considers that the person is suitable for registration under section 69, the Practitioners Board may approve the application.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Certificate of registration
section.content: Where a person has been registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner under section 69, the Registrar shall issue to him a certificate of registration in such form as may be determined by the Practitioners Board.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Certificate verifying registration and certificate of standing

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may, upon application by a person whose name appears in the Register, issue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certificate verifying registration; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a certificate of standing which shows the disciplinary record, if any, of that person.

subsection.content: A prescribed fee shall be payable in respect of each certificate referred to in subsection (1)(a) and (b).

section.name: s74
section.heading: Title of registered Chinese medicine practitioners

subsection.content: A registered Chinese medicine practitioner is entitled to be known in the English language as “registered Chinese medicine practitioner of the Chinese Medicine Council of Hong Kong” or the abbreviation “registered Chinese medicine practitioner” and in the Chinese language as “香港中醫藥管理委員會註冊中醫” or “香港中醫藥管理委員會註冊中醫師” or the abbreviation “註冊中醫” or “註冊中醫師”.

subsection.leadIn: In addition to the titles provided under subsection (1), a registered Chinese medicine practitioner may use the following addition or description to indicate his stream of practice in Chinese medicine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: general practice (全科);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: acupuncture (針灸);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: bone-setting (骨傷).

subsection.leadIn: Where a registered Chinese medicine practitioner desires to use the addition or description referred to in subsection (2), he shall adopt one of the following formats—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the English language as “Registered Chinese medicine practitioner of the Chinese Medicine Council of Hong Kong (General Practice)” or “Registered Chinese medicine practitioner of the Chinese Medicine Council of Hong Kong (Acupuncture)” or “Registered Chinese medicine practitioner of the Chinese Medicine Council of Hong Kong (Bone-setting)”; or in the Chinese language as “香港中醫藥管理委員會註冊中醫(全科)” or “香港中醫藥管理委員會註冊中醫(針灸)” or “香港中醫藥管理委員會註冊中醫(骨傷)”, as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the abbreviation in the English language as “Registered Chinese medicine practitioner (General Practice)” or “Registered Chinese medicine practitioner (Acupuncture)” or “Registered Chinese medicine practitioner (Bone-setting)”; or in the Chinese language as “註冊中醫(全科)” or “註冊中醫(針灸)” or “註冊中醫(骨傷)” or “註冊中醫師(全科)” or “註冊中醫師(針灸)” or “註冊中醫師(骨傷)”, as the case may be.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Privileges of registered and listed Chinese medicine practitioners

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 76, every registered Chinese medicine practitioner and listed Chinese medicine practitioner shall be entitled to practise Chinese medicine and to recover in any court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: reasonable charges for professional aid, advice and visits; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the value of any Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines or any Chinese medical appliances made or supplied by him to his patients.

subsection.content: No person shall be entitled to recover in any court any such charges as are referred to in subsection (1) unless at the date when such charges accrued he was a registered Chinese medicine practitioner or listed Chinese medicine practitioner.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Registered Chinese medicine practitioner not to practise without practising certificate

subsection.content: A registered Chinese medicine practitioner other than one registered under section 85 shall not practise Chinese medicine unless he is the holder of a practising certificate which is then in force.

subsection.leadIn: An application for the issue or renewal of a practising certificate may be made by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner to the Registrar in writing and shall be accompanied by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a prescribed fee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a declaration as to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: whether he has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: since his registration; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: since the last renewal of his practising certificate,

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: whether he has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: since his registration; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: since the last renewal of his practising certificate,

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of his having been so convicted or so found guilty of misconduct, the place and nature of each such offence or record of misconduct, as the case may be; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of renewal, such documents or certificates in relation to continuing education in Chinese medicine as may be required by the Practitioners Board.

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application under subsection (2), the Registrar may issue or renew the practising certificate specifying such conditions or restrictions as may be imposed if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the declaration referred to in subsection (2)(b) states to the effect that the registered Chinese medicine practitioner—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has not been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has not been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the documents or certificates referred to in subsection (2)(c) show that the registered Chinese medicine practitioner has complied with the requirements determined by the Practitioners Board under section 82.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Cases involving previous convictions and professional misconduct

subsection.content: If a registered Chinese medicine practitioner makes a declaration as required under section 76(2)(b) and declares that he has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of an offence punishable with imprisonment or that he has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect, the Registrar shall refer his case to the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners.

Where, pursuant to the consideration and recommendation by the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners, the Practitioners Board directs that the registered Chinese medicine practitioner be issued with a practising certificate or be granted with a renewal, as the case may be, the Registrar shall issue or renew the certificate specifying such conditions or restrictions as may be imposed.
Subject to subsection (2), a practising certificate shall be in force for such period not exceeding 3 years as may be specified in the certificate.

If at any time during the currency of a practising certificate, the holder of the certificate ceases to be a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, the certificate shall thereupon be deemed cancelled.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Obligations of practising certificate holders
section.leadIn: If at any time during the currency of a practising certificate, the holder of the practising certificate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of an offence punishable with imprisonment, he shall report the conviction to the Registrar forthwith;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect, he shall disclose the record of misconduct to the Registrar forthwith.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Deeming provision in relation to practising certificate

subsection.content: Any person who is required to be the holder of a practising certificate under section 76 shall be deemed to have obtained the practising certificate when he has duly applied to the Registrar and paid the prescribed fee in accordance with section 76(2).
Subsection (1) shall cease to apply once the application to the Registrar is approved or refused.

Notwithstanding subsection (1), a person who is required to be the holder of a practising certificate shall not be entitled to recover any fees, costs or other remuneration in his capacity as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner unless he was, at the time when the cause of action arose, the holder of a valid practising certificate.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Recovery of fees for practising certificates

subsection.content: If any registered Chinese medicine practitioner contravenes section 76(1), the amount of the prescribed fee payable by him under section 76(2) shall be recoverable as a civil debt by claim made in the name of the Registrar.

In any proceedings under this section a certificate purporting to be under the hand of the Registrar to the effect that the registered Chinese medicine practitioner concerned has not paid the prescribed fee shall, until the contrary is proved, be evidence of non-payment of the fee.

On recovery from a Chinese medicine practitioner of a prescribed fee under this section, the Registrar may, subject to the Chinese medicine practitioner’s name appearing on the Register and where applicable, subject to section 77, issue the Chinese medicine practitioner with the practising certificate.

The Practitioners Board may, on the advice of the Registration Committee, make arrangements for the accreditation of continuing education in Chinese medicine, either on its own or in conjunction with any other person or educational institution.

The Practitioners Board shall determine the requirements relating to continuing education in Chinese medicine which are to be complied with before a practising certificate may be renewed under section 76 or 77.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Limited Registration

subsection.leadIn: Where an educational or scientific research institution intends to engage a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who does not have any of the qualifications for registration referred to in section 67; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who has a qualification that qualifies him to apply to be registered but it is impracticable for him to obtain registration under section 69 in the circumstances,

subsection.continued: to perform predominantly clinical teaching or research in Chinese medicine for the institution, the institution may apply to the Practitioners Board on behalf of the person for limited registration of that person.

subsection.content: For the purpose of subsection (1), the Practitioners Board shall publish from time to time by notice in the Gazette a list of educational or scientific research institutions from which applications for limited registration will be considered.
For the avoidance of doubt, the notice published under subsection (2) is not subsidiary legislation.

subsection.leadIn: An application for limited registration shall be made to the Practitioners Board in such form as the Practitioners Board may determine and shall be accompanied by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such documents and particulars as may be determined by the Practitioners Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prescribed application fee.

subsection.content: For the purpose of determining an application for limited registration, the Practitioners Board may request the person on whose behalf the application is made to submit a declaration stating the same particulars as are required under section 68(3)(a).
Upon receipt of an application made under section 84(1), the Practitioners Board may refer the application to the Registration Committee.
The Registration Committee may, and if so directed by the Practitioners Board shall, make a report to the Practitioners Board.
In any report made to the Practitioners Board under subsection (2), the Registration Committee shall make recommendations to the Practitioners Board as to whether the application should be approved.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Practitioners Board is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the application for limited registration is made by an educational or scientific research institution specified under section 83(2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that the person on whose behalf the application was made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has satisfactorily completed such undergraduate degree course of training in Chinese medicine practice or its equivalent as is acceptable to the Practitioners Board; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: possesses adequate and relevant full-time experience in Chinese medicine practice,

subsection.continued: the Practitioners Board may, if the Registration Committee so recommends, direct that the person be registered as a Chinese medicine practitioner with limited registration subject to such conditions and restrictions regarding his practice as may be imposed by the Practitioners Board.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Limits of limited registration
section.leadIn: The limits of a person’s registration under section 85 shall be defined in the direction under the same section by specifying—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a period, not exceeding 1 year, as the period for which the registration is to have effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of the educational or scientific research institution in respect of which the registration has effect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the employment for performing predominantly clinical teaching or research in Chinese medicine in the named institution; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such conditions and restrictions regarding the practice of the Chinese medicine practitioner with limited registration, if any, as may be specified by the Practitioners Board.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Certificate of limited registration
section.content: When an application for limited registration is approved under section 85, the Registrar shall register the person on whose behalf the application was made in the Register and issue to him a certificate of limited registration in such form as may be determined by the Practitioners Board.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Refusal of application for limited registration

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may refuse an application for limited registration or renewal of such registration if it is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the requirements of section 85 have not been complied with;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: after due inquiry, that the person on whose behalf the application was made—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has been found guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in a professional respect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the institution which made the application or the person on whose behalf the application was made has sought to obtain registration by fraud or misrepresentation; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that it is reasonable in all circumstances to do so.

subsection.content: Where the Practitioners Board refuses an application, the secretary of the Practitioners Board shall notify the institution which made the application and the person on whose behalf the application was made in writing of the decision and the ground for refusal.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Provisions relating to renewal of limited registration

subsection.leadIn: Where an educational or scientific research institution which made an application under section 83 applies for renewal of registration, such registration shall, if the Practitioners Board so approves, be renewed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a period not exceeding 1 year from the expiry of the current registration;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of the clinical teaching or research in Chinese medicine in the educational or scientific research institution specified under sections 86(b) and (c); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions or restrictions regarding the practice of the Chinese medicine practitioner with limited registration, if any, as may be specified by the Practitioners Board.

subsection.content: Upon the approval of the Practitioners Board for the renewal of limited registration, a new certificate of limited registration may be issued by the Registrar on payment of a prescribed fee.

part.name: P9
part.heading: Transitional Arrangements for Chinese Medicine Practitioners

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board shall compile and maintain a list of Chinese medicine practitioners and shall enter on such list the name of any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is practising Chinese medicine on 3 January 2000;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has applied to the Practitioners Board for his name to be included in the list; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has paid a prescribed fee.

subsection.content: A person whose name is entered on the list under this section shall be assessed by the Practitioners Board as to whether he satisfies the requirements under section 92.

subsection.leadIn: A person referred to in subsection (2) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: continue practising Chinese medicine, subject to such conditions and restrictions as may be imposed and notified in writing by the Practitioners Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: use the title of “Chinese medicine practitioner” in the English language and “中醫” or “中醫師” in the Chinese language,

subsection.continued: until—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: his name has been entered on the Register under section 69(4);

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: his application for registration, if any, has been refused under section 70;

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: his name has been removed from the list under section 91; or

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: such date as may be specified and promulgated by the Secretary by notice in the Gazette,

subsection.continued: whichever is the earliest.

subsection.content: Where the Practitioners Board has imposed conditions or restrictions under subsection (3)(a), it may amend, vary or revoke any of such conditions or restrictions.
The list maintained under this section shall remain open for application for inclusion by Chinese medicine practitioners within such period of time as may be determined by the Practitioners Board.
