The Practitioners Board may arrange to publish in the Gazette from time to time as it thinks appropriate the list maintained by it under this section.

Nothing in this section shall operate so as to prohibit any person who was practising Chinese medicine immediately prior to the commencement of this provision from continuing to practise in accordance with this Ordinance until after the expiry of the period of time referred to in subsection (5).

Where a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of subsection (7) would, but for this subsection, be liable to be prosecuted for an offence under section 108(1)(c) and (2), then the person shall not be so liable until after the expiry of the period of time referred to in subsection (5) notwithstanding that on the expiry of such period of time, no application under subsection (1)(b) has been made to the Practitioners Board.

editorialNote.content: * Section 90(8) is not yet in operation — see L.N. 250 of 2000.

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board shall remove from the list maintained under section 90 the name of a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who becomes registered under section 69; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whose application for registration, if any, is refused under section 70.

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may remove from the list maintained under section 90 the name of a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is subject to the conditions or restrictions imposed under section 90(3)(a) but has failed to comply with any of such conditions or restrictions; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of an offence punishable with imprisonment.

subsection.content: The Practitioners Board shall notify the person concerned in writing of the reasons for its direction under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may determine a person to be qualified to be registered under section 69 if it is satisfied, after assessment, that the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is one whose name is entered on the list maintained under section 90; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has acquired substantial experience, knowledge and skills in the practice of Chinese medicine.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall be regarded as having acquired substantial experience, knowledge and skills for the purpose of subsection (1)(b) unless he has—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attained the standard which qualifies him to be exempted from the Licensing Examination under section 93;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: passed the registration assessment as required under section 94; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: passed the Licensing Examination as required under section 95.

section.name: s93
section.heading: Exemptions from Licensing Examination
section.leadIn: A listed Chinese medicine practitioner who satisfies the Practitioners Board that he has fulfilled either one of the following criteria, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: immediately before 3 January 2000, he has been practising Chinese medicine in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 15 years; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: immediately before 3 January 2000, he has been practising Chinese medicine in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 10 years; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he has obtained a qualification in Chinese medicine practice acceptable to the Practitioners Board,

section.continued: shall be exempted from the Licensing Examination.

subsection.leadIn: A listed Chinese medicine practitioner who satisfies the Practitioners Board that he has fulfilled either one of the following criteria, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: immediately before 3 January 2000, he has been practising Chinese medicine in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 10 years; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: immediately before 3 January 2000, he has been practising Chinese medicine in Hong Kong for a continuous period of less than 10 years; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he has obtained a qualification in Chinese medicine practice acceptable to the Practitioners Board,

subsection.continued: shall be exempted from the Licensing Examination but shall be required to pass a registration assessment conducted by the Practitioners Board before he is qualified to apply to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner under section 69.

subsection.content: A listed Chinese medicine practitioner who is required to undergo the registration assessment shall pay a prescribed fee before he may attend the registration assessment.
The Practitioners Board shall publish by notice in the Gazette such information pertaining to the registration assessment as it thinks fit.
For the avoidance of doubt, the notice published under subsection (3) is not subsidiary legislation.

subsection.leadIn: A listed Chinese medicine practitioner who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: satisfies the Practitioners Board that immediately before 3 January 2000, he has been practising Chinese medicine in Hong Kong for a continuous period of less than 10 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has failed the registration assessment,

subsection.continued: shall be required to undertake the Licensing Examination, the passing of which shall qualify him to apply to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner under section 69.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (1)(b), a listed Chinese medicine practitioner who has made a request for review under section 96 shall not be required to undertake the Licensing Examination pending the outcome of the review.
Where a registration assessment is conducted under section 94, the Practitioners Board shall notify the listed Chinese medicine practitioner concerned in writing of the relevant result.

Within 14 days of the receipt of the written notification made in accordance with subsection (1), the listed Chinese medicine practitioner concerned may request the Practitioners Board to review the result of the registration assessment, to which the written notification relates, by submitting the request in writing and stating the reasons relied upon.

Upon receipt of a request for review under subsection (2) and payment of a prescribed review fee, the Practitioners Board shall review the result and notify the listed Chinese medicine practitioner in writing of its decision within 1 month after the completion of the review.

part.name: P10
part.heading: Appeals, Disciplinary Powers and Inquiries

subsection.content: Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Practitioners Board made under sections 56(1)(c), 58(4), 59(2), 61(1)(a), 62, 63, 64, 66, 70 and 88 may, within 14 days of the receipt of the notification of the decision, or within such further time as the Council may in special circumstances allow, appeal against that decision to the Council in writing stating the reasons relied upon.
In determining an appeal under subsection (1), the Council may invite the person concerned to give further representations in writing or in person.
For the purpose of hearing an appeal, 5 members of the Council shall be a quorum.
A hearing of an appeal shall be conducted in accordance with the prescribed procedure.
The Council may affirm, reverse or vary the decision appealed against.
The decision of the Council under subsection (5) shall be final.

Where the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners considers that the conduct of a registered Chinese medicine practitioner should be inquired into as a result of a complaint being made to it or otherwise, the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners shall refer the case to the Practitioners Board.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Practitioners Board is satisfied, after due inquiry into the case referred to it under subsection (1), that the registered Chinese medicine practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been convicted in Hong Kong or elsewhere of any offence punishable with imprisonment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is guilty in Hong Kong or elsewhere of misconduct in any professional respect; (Amended 9 of 2002 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has obtained registration by fraud or misrepresentation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: was not at the time of his registration qualified to be registered;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: has breached a condition or conditions imposed by the Practitioners Board on his practice of Chinese medicine;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: has failed to disclose a conviction in Hong Kong or elsewhere of an offence punishable with imprisonment to the Registrar in accordance with section 79(a); or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: has failed to disclose a record of misconduct in any professional respect to the Registrar in accordance with section 79(b),

subsection.continued: the Practitioners Board may take any of the steps in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The Practitioners Board may, in its discretion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order that the name of the registered Chinese medicine practitioner be removed from the Register;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order that the name of the registered Chinese medicine practitioner be removed from the Register for such period as it may think fit and that the name be subsequently restored to the Register upon the expiry of such period;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make any such order as in paragraph (a) or (b) but suspend its application, subject to such conditions as it thinks fit, for a period, or periods in aggregate, not exceeding 3 years;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: order that the registered Chinese medicine practitioner be reprimanded;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: make any such order as in paragraph (a) or (b) and further order that such order takes effect upon its publication in the Gazette if the Practitioners Board is satisfied that it is necessary for the protection of the public to do so; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: order that a warning letter be served on the registered Chinese medicine practitioner.

subsection.content: Where an order is made under subsection (3), the Practitioners Board may, in any case, make such order as it thinks fit with regard to the payment of costs of the Registrar, any complainant or any person presenting the case to the Practitioners Board and the registered Chinese medicine practitioner and any costs awarded may be recovered summarily as a civil debt in accordance with the provision of section 67 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

subsection.leadIn: Except for an order made under subsection (3)(e), the Registrar shall not remove the name of the registered Chinese medicine practitioner from the Register—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: until after the expiry of the time within which an appeal may be lodged under section 103(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an appeal having in fact been lodged under section 103(1), until after the appeal is finally determined. (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 122)

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be deemed to require the Practitioners Board to inquire into the question as to whether a registered Chinese medicine practitioner was properly convicted when considering a record of conviction of the Chinese medicine practitioner under this section, but the Practitioners Board may consider any record of the case in which such conviction was recorded and any other evidence which may be available and is relevant as showing the nature and gravity of the offence.

In deciding whether the Practitioners Board should be recommended to hold an inquiry under this section in respect of a case, the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners shall act in accordance with the prescribed procedure for considering the case brought to its attention.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Meetings of Practitioners Board for purpose of an inquiry

subsection.content: The meetings of the Practitioners Board held for the purpose of conducting an inquiry under section 98 shall require a quorum of 5 members subject to at least one being a lay member.
Only members who have attended all meetings held for the purpose of the inquiry may participate in the decision of the Practitioners Board.

A member of the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners who is also a member of the Practitioners Board shall not attend a meeting of the Practitioners Board held for the purpose of inquiring into a case, if that member has taken part in its initial consideration when it was brought before the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Powers of Practitioners Board in regard to obtaining of evidence and conduct at proceedings

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of conducting an inquiry under section 98, the Practitioners Board shall have the following powers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to hear, receive and examine evidence on oath;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to summon any person to attend the inquiry to give evidence or produce any book, document or other thing in his possession and to examine him as a witness or require him to produce any book, document or other thing in his possession;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to admit or exclude the public or any member of the public from the inquiry;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to award any person summoned to attend the inquiry such sum or sums as in the opinion of the Practitioners Board may have been reasonably expended by him for attending the inquiry.

subsection.content: Summonses to witnesses may be in such form as the Practitioners Board may determine and shall be signed by the chairman of the Practitioners Board.
A summons to witness may be served personally, by post or by registered post.

If it appears to the Practitioners Board that it is necessary to do so in the interests of the complainant, any witness concerned or the registered Chinese medicine practitioner who is the subject of an inquiry, it may order that all or any information relating to the inquiry may not be disclosed.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Appearance of counsel, etc.
section.content: The complainant in an inquiry under section 98 or the registered Chinese medicine practitioner whose conduct is the subject of such inquiry shall be entitled to be represented by a solicitor or counsel throughout the inquiry.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Service of orders made by Practitioners Board

subsection.content: A copy of any order made under section 98(3)(a), (b), (c) or (e) shall be served by the Registrar upon the registered Chinese medicine practitioner concerned.

Where the Practitioners Board made an order under section 98(3)(d) or (f), the Registrar shall serve the reprimand or the warning letter together with the relevant order upon the registered Chinese medicine practitioner concerned.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Appeals against orders of Practitioners Board

subsection.content: Any person who is aggrieved by an order made in respect of him under section 56(1)(a), (d) or (e) or (2) or 98 may, within 1 month from the date of service of the order, or within such further time as the Court of Appeal may in special circumstances allow, appeal to the Court of Appeal.
The Court of Appeal may affirm, reverse or vary the order appealed against.
The practice in relation to any such appeal shall be subject to any rules of court made under the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4).
The Court of Appeal shall not have power to hear any appeal against an order made under section 98 unless notice of such appeal was given within the time referred to in subsection (1).
Where an order under section 98(3)(e) is made, the Practitioners Board shall, as soon as possible, publish the order in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 98(3)(a), (b), (c) or (d) is made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the time specified under section 103(1) within which an appeal against an order may be lodged has expired; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no such appeal has been lodged,

subsection.continued: the Practitioners Board shall, within 1 month, publish the order in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 98(3)(f) is made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the time specified under section 103(1) within which an appeal against an order may be lodged has expired; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no such appeal has been lodged,

subsection.continued: the Practitioners Board may, if it sees fit, within 1 month, publish the order in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 98(3)(a), (b), (c) or (d) is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged against the order within the time limit specified under section 103(1),

subsection.continued: the Practitioners Board shall within 1 month after the appeal is finally determined, publish the order or, if the order is varied on appeal, the order as so varied in the Gazette. (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 123)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 98(3)(f) is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an appeal has been lodged against the order within the time limit specified under section 103(1),

subsection.continued: the Practitioners Board may, as it sees fit, within 1 month after the appeal is finally determined, publish the order or, if the order is varied on appeal, the order as so varied in the Gazette. (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 123)

subsection.leadIn: Where an order is published in the Gazette under subsection (1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) the Practitioners Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall publish with such order sufficient particulars to acquaint the public with the nature of the matter to which the order relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may publish with such order an account of the proceedings of the inquiry at which the order was made.

part.name: P11
part.heading: Offences

section.name: s105
section.heading: Penalty for failure to give evidence

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), any person who being summoned to attend as a witness or to produce a book, document or any other thing at an inquiry under section 100(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuses or neglects to do so; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: refuses to answer any question put to him—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by the Practitioners Board; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: with the concurrence of the Practitioners Board,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (1), no person shall be bound to incriminate himself and every witness shall, in respect of any evidence given by him before the Practitioners Board, be entitled to the privileges to which he would be entitled if giving evidence before a court of justice.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Penalty for not complying with an order regarding non-disclosure of information
section.content: A person who does not comply with an order under section 100(4) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Fraudulent registration, etc.
section.content: Any person who fraudulently procures or attempts to procure himself or any other person to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner or to be listed as a listed Chinese medicine practitioner, by making or producing, or causing to be made or produced, any false or fraudulent representations or declaration, either oral or in writing, commits an offence and is liable on conviction upon indictment to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Unlawful use of title, etc. and practise without registration

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: wilfully or falsely pretends—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to be qualified to practise Chinese medicine; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to be a listed Chinese medicine practitioner; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to be a registered Chinese medicine practitioner; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: that his name is included in the Register; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: falsely takes or uses any name, title, addition or description implying that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he is qualified to practise Chinese medicine; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is a listed Chinese medicine practitioner; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: he is a registered Chinese medicine practitioner; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: his name is included in the Register; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not being a registered Chinese medicine practitioner or listed Chinese medicine practitioner, professes to practise or publishes his name as practising Chinese medicine,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), any person who not being a registered Chinese medicine practitioner or listed Chinese medicine practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: practises Chinese medicine commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: practises Chinese medicine in relation to a person which results in personal injury to that person commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: on conviction upon indictment to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) shall not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the dispensing of Chinese herbal medicines by a dispenser or person nominated under section 114(2)(b)(i) or (ii) at the premises in respect of which a retailer licence is in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the use of acupuncture, being of a type with distinguishable differences from acupuncture based on traditional Chinese medicine, in the course of the practice of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a registered medical practitioner registered under the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a registered dentist registered under the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a physiotherapist registered under the Allied Health Professions Ordinance (Cap. 359). (Amended 33 of 2025 s. 204)

subsection.leadIn: Any person with limited registration who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: wilfully or falsely pretends to be qualified to practise Chinese medicine; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: wilfully or falsely takes or uses any name, title, addition or description implying that he is qualified to practise Chinese medicine,

subsection.continued: beyond the limits defined in the direction under sections 85 and 86 relating to that registration commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the suggestion of a well-established prescription of Chinese herbal medicines to a single individual without carrying out any diagnosis on the basis of traditional Chinese medicine by a dispenser or person nominated under section 114(2)(b)(i) or (ii) at the premises in respect of which a retailer licence is in force shall not be regarded as practising Chinese medicine for the purpose of subsection (2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who fraudulently procures himself to be registered as a registered Chinese medicine practitioner or listed as a listed Chinese medicine practitioner, by making or producing, or causing to be made or produced, any false or fraudulent representations or declaration, either oral or in writing, shall be deemed not to have been so registered or so listed, as the case may be.

part.name: P12
part.heading: Licensing of Chinese Herbal Medicines Traders

section.name: s109
section.heading: Restriction on sale, etc. of Schedule 1 medicines

subsection.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell by retail; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dispense to another person,

subsection.continued: any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 1—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: except in accordance with a prescription given by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: without a retailer licence in respect of such Chinese herbal medicine; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: subject to section 145(1), at any place other than the premises specified in such licence.

subsection.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell or distribute by way of wholesale; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: possess for the purpose of wholesale,

subsection.continued: any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 1—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: without a wholesaler licence in Chinese herbal medicines in respect of such Chinese herbal medicine; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: subject to section 145(1), at any place other than the premises specified in such licence.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Possession of Schedule 1 medicines
section.content: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall have in his possession any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 1, unless the Chinese herbal medicine is possessed under and in accordance with a licence granted by the Medicines Board under this Ordinance.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Restriction on sale, etc. of Schedule 2 medicines

subsection.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell by retail; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dispense to another person; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: possess for the purpose of retail,

subsection.continued: any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 2—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: without a retailer licence in respect of such Chinese herbal medicine; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: subject to section 145(1), at any place other than the premises specified in such licence.

subsection.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell or distribute by way of wholesale; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: possess for the purpose of wholesale,

subsection.continued: any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 2—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: without a wholesaler licence in Chinese herbal medicines in respect of such Chinese herbal medicine; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: subject to section 145(1), at any place other than the premises specified in such licence.

section.name: s112
section.heading: Application of Schedules 1 and 2
section.content: The Chinese herbal medicines specified in Schedules 1 and 2 shall apply to the dried or processed form of such medicines unless otherwise specified.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Amendment of Schedules 1 and 2
section.content: The Secretary may, after the consultation with the Council, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedules 1 and 2.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Licensing of retailers in Chinese herbal medicines

subsection.content: Any person may apply to the Medicines Board for a retailer licence.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in such form and accompanied by such documents, information and particulars as the Medicines Board may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: include the following nominations—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person who will be responsible for the supervision of the dispensing of Chinese herbal medicines; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: not more than 2 deputies, one of whom shall act in the absence of that person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the Chinese herbal medicines to which the application relates; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: specify the location of the premises to which the application relates.

subsection.content: If the Medicines Board is satisfied that an application under subsection (1) complies with the prescribed licensing requirements, it may, upon payment of a prescribed fee, issue a retailer licence subject to such restrictions or conditions as may be imposed.

If, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so, it may refuse an application under subsection (1) and thereupon notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Licensing of wholesale dealers in Chinese herbal medicines

subsection.content: Any person may apply to the Medicines Board for a wholesaler licence in Chinese herbal medicines.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in such form and accompanied by such documents, information and particulars as the Medicines Board may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the Chinese herbal medicines to which the application relates; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the location of the premises to which the application relates.

subsection.content: If the Medicines Board is satisfied that an application under subsection (1) complies with the prescribed licensing requirements, it may, upon payment of a prescribed fee, issue a wholesaler licence in Chinese herbal medicines subject to such restrictions or conditions as may be imposed.

If, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so, it may refuse an application under subsection (1) and thereupon notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.
Subject to section 139, a licence issued under section 114 or 115 shall be for such period as may be prescribed.
A licence holder may apply to the Medicines Board for the renewal of the licence.

subsection.leadIn: On an application for renewal under this section, the Medicines Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: upon payment of a prescribed fee, renew the licence, with or without modifications to the conditions or restrictions, if any, previously imposed and for such period as may be prescribed or for such shorter period as it considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse the application, if, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, it considers it necessary in the public interest to do so.

subsection.content: Where the Medicines Board refuses an application for renewal under this section, it shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Certified copy of licences
section.content: The Medicines Board may, upon application and payment of a prescribed fee by the holder of a licence issued under this Part, issue a certified copy of that licence to the licence holder.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Provision for transitional licensing of Chinese herbal medicines traders

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carries on a business in the retail or wholesale of Chinese herbal medicines on 3 January 2000; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes an application to the Medicines Board within such period of time as may be determined by the Medicines Board for a retailer licence or wholesaler licence in Chinese herbal medicines, as the case may be, in accordance with section 114 or 115,

subsection.continued: shall be deemed, under this subsection, to have been granted a licence issued under section 114 or 115 as appropriate, subject to such terms and conditions as may be imposed by the Medicines Board by notice in writing to that person, and the licence shall, subject to section 139, continue in effect until—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the issue of a licence under section 114(3) or 115(3), as the case may be;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the refusal of his application for a licence under section 114(4) or 115(4), as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: such date as may be specified and promulgated by the Secretary by notice published in the Gazette,

subsection.continued: whichever is the earliest.

subsection.content: Confirmation in writing by the Medicines Board of the receipt of an application shall be sufficient evidence of a licence deemed to be granted under subsection (1).

Where a person would, but for this subsection, be liable to be prosecuted for a contravention of section 109, 110 or 111 for trading in or possessing any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 1 or 2 without a licence, then that person shall not be so liable until after the expiry of the period of time referred to in subsection (1)(b) notwithstanding that on the expiry of such period of time, no application has been made to the Medicines Board.

part.name: P13
part.heading: Registration of Proprietary Chinese Medicines

section.name: s119
section.heading: Proprietary Chinese medicines to be registered

subsection.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance and subject to subsection (2), no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: import; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: possess,

subsection.continued: any proprietary Chinese medicine unless the proprietary Chinese medicine is registered under section 121.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) shall not apply to any substance or product which is registered under the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138).

Nothing in subsection (1) shall operate so as to prohibit a manufacturer from manufacturing or a wholesaler of proprietary Chinese medicine from importing a proprietary Chinese medicine of a reasonable quantity for the purposes of providing samples and seeking registration under section 121.

For the purpose of subsection (1), a proprietary Chinese medicine shall not be taken as registered under section 121 unless its particulars are identical with the registered particulars of the registered proprietary Chinese medicine.

section.name: s120
section.heading: Application for registration of proprietary Chinese medicines to be made by manufacturers, importers, etc.
section.leadIn: An application for the registration of a proprietary Chinese medicine shall be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of its being manufactured in Hong Kong, by the manufacturer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of its being manufactured outside Hong Kong—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by the importer; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by the local representative or agent of the manufacturer,

paragraph.continued: prior to its being imported into Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: An application for the registration of a proprietary Chinese medicine shall be made to the Medicines Board and shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in such form and accompanied by such documents, information, samples and other materials as the Medicines Board may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: furnish the particulars of the proprietary Chinese medicine required to be registered in accordance with the prescribed requirements; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be accompanied by a prescribed application fee.

subsection.content: Subject to section 122, the Medicines Board may approve the application and upon payment of a prescribed issue fee, register the proprietary Chinese medicine and issue a certificate of registration to the applicant in respect of the proprietary Chinese medicine in such form as it may determine.

Subject to the certificate of registration being issued, the Medicines Board may impose such conditions as it thinks fit and may amend, vary or revoke the conditions if it appears to the Medicines Board that the conditions should be amended, varied or revoked.

If, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so, it may refuse an application for registration made under subsection (1) and thereupon notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.

section.name: s122
section.heading: Factors relevant to determination of application for registration

subsection.leadIn: In determining an application for registration of a proprietary Chinese medicine, the Medicines Board shall in particular take into consideration—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the safety of the proprietary Chinese medicine to which the application relates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the quality of the proprietary Chinese medicine according to the specification and the method or proposed method of manufacture of the medicine, and the provisions proposed for securing that medicine as sold or supplied will be of that quality; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the efficacy of the proprietary Chinese medicine for the purposes for which the medicine is proposed to be administered.

subsection.content: In taking into consideration the efficacy for a particular purpose of a proprietary Chinese medicine to which an application relates, the Medicines Board shall disregard any question whether a proprietary Chinese medicine of another description would or might be equally or more efficacious for that purpose.

For the purpose of subsection (1), nothing in subsection (2) shall be construed as requiring the Medicines Board, in considering the safety of a proprietary Chinese medicine of a particular description, in relation to a purpose for which it is proposed to be administered, to disregard any question whether a proprietary Chinese medicine of another description, being equally or more efficacious for that purpose, would or might be safer in relation to that purpose.

subsection.leadIn: In determining an application relating to a proprietary Chinese medicine which is to be imported, the Medicines Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall also take into consideration in particular the methods, standards and conditions of manufacture of the medicine; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may, if it thinks fit, require the production by the applicant of any one or a combination of the following—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an undertaking, given by the manufacturer of the proprietary Chinese medicine, to permit the premises where it is or is to be manufactured, and the operations carried on or to be carried on in the course of manufacturing it, to be inspected by or on behalf of the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an undertaking, given by the manufacturer of the proprietary Chinese medicine, to comply with any conditions as imposed by the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a declaration, given by or on behalf of the manufacturer of the proprietary Chinese medicine that, in relation to the manufacture of the proprietary Chinese medicine any requirements imposed by or under the law of the place in which it is or is to be manufactured have been or will be complied with.

subsection.content: The registration of a proprietary Chinese medicine under section 121 shall have effect for such period as may be prescribed.
The holder of a certificate of registration may apply to the Medicines Board for the renewal of registration.

subsection.leadIn: On an application for renewal under this section, the Medicines Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: upon payment of a prescribed fee, renew the registration and issue a certificate of registration, with or without modifications to the conditions, if any, previously imposed for such period as may be prescribed or for such shorter period as it considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse the application, if, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, it considers it necessary in the public interest to do so.

subsection.content: Where the Medicines Board refuses an application for renewal under this section, it shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.

section.name: s124
section.heading: Variation of registered particulars of registered proprietary Chinese medicines

subsection.leadIn: The holder of a certificate of registration may, on payment of a prescribed fee, apply in writing to the Medicines Board for approval to vary the registered particulars of the proprietary Chinese medicine to which the certificate relates except the following particulars—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the product name;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the dose form; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the name and quantity of any active ingredient.

subsection.content: If the Medicines Board is satisfied that the proposed variation will not adversely affect the safety, quality and efficacy of the relevant proprietary Chinese medicine, it may approve the variation as proposed in the application.

subsection.leadIn: The Medicines Board shall advise the applicant in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the application for variation is approved; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it is approved, the date on which the variation takes effect; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if it is disapproved, the reason for disapproval.

subsection.content: Where the variation of the registered particulars of a proprietary Chinese medicine registered under section 121 takes effect, the proprietary Chinese medicine to which the registered particulars were related before the variation shall cease to be a proprietary Chinese medicine registered under that section.

Where by virtue of subsection (4) a proprietary Chinese medicine ceases to be a proprietary Chinese medicine registered under section 121, the relevant applicant shall before the relevant variation takes effect, recall or cause to recall, to the extent reasonably possible, the proprietary Chinese medicine already supplied.
The Medicines Board may de-register a proprietary Chinese medicine if it considers it necessary in the public interest to do so.

Where the Medicines Board intends to de-register a proprietary Chinese medicine, it shall notify the holder of the certificate of registration in writing of its intention and invite him to submit any representations, information or explanation in writing.
Notwithstanding subsection (2), the Medicines Board may de-register a proprietary Chinese medicine forthwith if it considers that an emergency exists.

Where the Medicines Board determines to de-register a proprietary Chinese medicine, it shall forward to the holder of the certificate of registration a notice of de-registration and shall state in such notice its reasons for de-registration.
The Medicines Board may publish in the Gazette a list of all proprietary Chinese medicines de-registered under subsections (1) and (3) when it considers appropriate.

section.name: s126
section.heading: Publication of registered proprietary Chinese medicines
section.content: The Medicines Board may publish in the Gazette from time to time as it considers appropriate a list of registered proprietary Chinese medicines.

section.name: s127
section.heading: Certified copy of certificate of registration
section.content: The Medicines Board may, upon application and payment of a prescribed fee by the holder of a certificate of registration issued under this Part, issue a certified copy of that certificate of registration to the certificate holder.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Provision for transitional registration of proprietary Chinese medicines

subsection.leadIn: Where a proprietary Chinese medicine is, on 1 March 1999—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: manufactured, sold or supplied for sale in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: manufactured outside Hong Kong and is sold or supplied for sale in Hong Kong,

subsection.continued: a person who is, on the same date—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: in the case of paragraph (a), the manufacturer; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: in the case of paragraph (b), an importer, or a local representative or agent of the manufacturer,

subsection.continued: may apply to the Medicines Board within such period of time as may be determined by the Medicines Board for the registration of the proprietary Chinese medicine in accordance with section 121.

subsection.content: Where an application is made under subsection (1), the proprietary Chinese medicine shall be deemed, under this subsection, to have been registered and a certificate is deemed to have been issued under section 121 subject to such classification of category, conditions and restrictions as may be imposed by the Medicines Board by notice in writing to the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (7), such registration shall continue in effect until—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the issue of a certificate of registration under section 121(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the refusal of the application for registration of that proprietary Chinese medicine under section 121(4); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: such date as may be specified and promulgated by the Secretary by notice published in the Gazette,

subsection.continued: whichever is the earliest.

subsection.content: Confirmation in writing by the Medicines Board of the receipt of an application shall be sufficient evidence of a certificate deemed to be issued under subsection (2).
The Medicines Board may amend, vary or revoke any of the classification of category, conditions or restrictions imposed under subsection (2).

Where a person would, but for this subsection, be liable to be prosecuted for a contravention of section 119 for trading in, importing or possessing a proprietary Chinese medicine which, but for this subsection, would otherwise be required to be registered, then the person shall not be so liable until after the expiry of the period of time referred to in subsection (1) notwithstanding that on the expiry of such period of time, no application has been made to the Medicines Board.

Section 125 and any requirements in respect of proprietary Chinese medicines imposed by regulations made under section 161 shall apply to proprietary Chinese medicines deemed to be registered under this section.

For the purpose of facilitating the conduct of a clinical trial or medicinal test of any proprietary Chinese medicine, the Medicines Board may, upon application, issue a certificate for clinical trial and medicinal test.
An application shall be in such form and accompanied by such documents, information, samples and other materials as the Medicines Board may determine and a prescribed application fee.

The Medicines Board may, on payment of a prescribed issue fee, issue a certificate for clinical trial and medicinal test, and such certificate shall be valid for such period and subject to such conditions as the Medicines Board thinks fit.
If, having regard to the provisions of this Ordinance, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so, it may refuse an application made under subsection (1).

section.name: s130
section.heading: Certificate of sale of proprietary Chinese medicines

subsection.content: For the purpose of exporting a proprietary Chinese medicine which is registered under section 121 and manufactured by a manufacturer licensed under section 132, the Medicines Board may, upon application, issue in the prescribed form a certificate certifying that the proprietary Chinese medicine is allowed to be sold in Hong Kong and containing such statements relating to the proprietary Chinese medicine as it considers appropriate.
The certificate referred to in subsection (1) is issued subject to the payment of a prescribed fee.

part.name: P14
part.heading: Licensing of Proprietary Chinese Medicines Traders

section.name: s131
section.heading: Restriction on manufacture of proprietary Chinese medicines
section.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall manufacture any proprietary Chinese medicine, whether registered or not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without a manufacturer licence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to section 145(1), at any place other than the premises specified in such licence.

subsection.leadIn: An application for a licence to manufacture proprietary Chinese medicines shall be made to the Medicines Board and shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in such form and accompanied by such documents, particulars and other materials as the Medicines Board may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: include the following nominations—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person who will be responsible for the supervision of the manufacture of proprietary Chinese medicines; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: not more than 2 deputies, one of whom shall act in the absence of that person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the location of the premises to which the application relates.

subsection.content: If the Medicines Board is satisfied that an application made under subsection (1) complies with the prescribed licensing requirements, it may, upon payment of a prescribed fee, issue a manufacturer licence in a prescribed form subject to such conditions or restrictions as may be imposed. (Amended 14 of 2003 s. 24)

Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (2), the Medicines Board may impose a condition prohibiting the manufacturing of certain proprietary Chinese medicines if the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so.

If, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so, it may refuse an application made under subsection (1) and thereupon notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Certificate for manufacturer
section.content: The Medicines Board may, upon application and payment of a prescribed fee, issue a certificate in a prescribed form, to be known as a certificate for manufacturer, certifying that the holder of a manufacturer licence follows the requirements of good practices in manufacture and quality control of proprietary Chinese medicines.

section.name: s134
section.heading: Restriction on sale, etc. of proprietary Chinese medicines
section.leadIn: Except under and in accordance with this Ordinance, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell or distribute by way of wholesale; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: possess for the purpose of wholesale,

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: without a wholesaler licence in proprietary Chinese medicines; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: subject to section 145(1), at any place other than the premises specified in such licence.

section.name: s135
section.heading: Licensing of wholesale dealers in proprietary Chinese medicines

subsection.leadIn: An application for a wholesaler licence in proprietary Chinese medicines shall be made to the Medicines Board and shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in such form and accompanied by such documents, particulars and other materials as the Medicines Board may determine; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the location of the premises to which the application relates.

subsection.content: If the Medicines Board is satisfied that an application made under subsection (1) complies with the prescribed licensing requirements, it may, upon payment of a prescribed fee, issue a wholesaler licence in proprietary Chinese medicines subject to such restrictions or conditions as it may impose.

If, having regard to the provisions of this Ordinance, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so, it may refuse an application made under subsection (1) and thereupon notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.
Subject to section 139, a licence issued under section 132 or 135 shall be for such period as may be prescribed.
A licence holder may apply to the Medicines Board for the renewal of the licence.

subsection.leadIn: On an application for renewal under this section, the Medicines Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: upon payment of a prescribed fee, renew the licence, with or without modifications to the conditions or restrictions, if any, previously imposed and for such period as may be prescribed or for such shorter period as it considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse the application, if, having regard to the provisions of the Ordinance, it considers it necessary in the public interest to do so.

subsection.content: Where the Medicines Board refuses an application for renewal under this section, it shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for refusal.

section.name: s137
section.heading: Certified copy of licences, etc.
section.content: The Medicines Board may, upon application and payment of a prescribed fee by the holder of a licence or certificate issued under this Part, issue a certified copy of that licence or certificate to the relevant holder.

section.name: s138
section.heading: Provision for transitional licensing of proprietary Chinese medicines traders

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: carries on a business in the manufacture or wholesale of proprietary Chinese medicines on 3 January 2000; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes an application to the Medicines Board within such period of time as may be determined by the Medicines Board for a manufacturer or wholesaler licence in proprietary Chinese medicines, as the case may be, in accordance with section 132 or 135,

subsection.continued: shall be deemed to have been granted a licence under section 132 or 135 as appropriate, subject to such terms and conditions as may be imposed by the Medicines Board by notice in writing to the applicant, and the licence shall, subject to section 139, continue in effect until—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the issue of a licence under section 132(2) or 135(2), as the case may be;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the refusal of the application for a licence under section 132(4) or 135(3), as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: such date as may be specified or promulgated by the Secretary by notice published in the Gazette,

subsection.continued: whichever is the earliest.

subsection.content: Confirmation in writing by the Medicines Board of the receipt of an application shall be sufficient evidence of a licence deemed to be granted under subsection (1).

Where a person would, but for this subsection, be liable to be prosecuted for a contravention of section 131 or 134 for manufacturing, trading in or possessing any proprietary Chinese medicine without a licence, then the person shall not be so liable until after the expiry of the period of time referred to in subsection (1)(b) notwithstanding that on the expiry of such period of time, no application has been made to the Medicines Board.

part.name: P14A
part.heading: Chinese Medicine Safety Order

section.name: s138A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—

def.name: ChineseMedicineOrRelatedProduct
def.leadIn: Chinese medicine or related product (中藥或相關產品) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Chinese herbal medicine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a proprietary Chinese medicine; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an intermediate product;

section.def: Chinese medicine safety order (中藥安全令) means an order made under section 138B(1);

intermediate product (中間產品) means a substance or compound that is generated in the course of manufacture of a proprietary Chinese medicine and that is to be used in the further preparation or production process of the medicine.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Making of Chinese Medicine Safety Order

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by order in writing, do either or both of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prohibit the sale of a Chinese medicine or related product;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct that a Chinese medicine or related product that has been sold be recalled and specify the way in which, and the period within which, the recall is to be conducted.

subsection.content: The grounds on which a Chinese medicine safety order may be made are set out in sections 138C and 138D.

section.name: s138C
section.heading: Grounds for prohibiting sale
section.leadIn: The Director may make an order under section 138B(1)(a) only if the Director has reasonable grounds to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a Chinese herbal medicine—

subparagraph.content: the medicine has been sold or distributed in contravention of section 109(2) or 111(2);
the medicine is dangerous or injurious to health, or unfit for use by human beings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a proprietary Chinese medicine—

subparagraph.content: the medicine has been sold in contravention of section 119(1), 143 or 144;
the medicine has been sold or distributed in contravention of section 134;
the medicine has been manufactured in contravention of section 131;
the medicine is dangerous or injurious to health, or unfit for use by human beings; or
the order is necessary to prevent or reduce a possibility of danger to public health, or to mitigate any adverse consequence of a danger to public health; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for an intermediate product—

subparagraph.content: the product is dangerous or injurious to health, or unfit for use by human beings; or
the order is necessary to prevent or reduce a possibility of danger to public health, or to mitigate any adverse consequence of a danger to public health.

section.name: s138D
section.heading: Grounds for directing recall
section.leadIn: The Director may make an order under section 138B(1)(b) only if the Director has reasonable grounds to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a Chinese herbal medicine—

subparagraph.content: the medicine has been sold or dispensed in contravention of section 109(1) or 111(1);
the medicine has been sold or distributed in contravention of section 109(2) or 111(2);
the medicine is dangerous or injurious to health, or unfit for use by human beings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a proprietary Chinese medicine—

subparagraph.content: the medicine has been sold in contravention of section 119(1), 143 or 144;
the medicine has been sold or distributed in contravention of section 134;
the medicine has been manufactured in contravention of section 131;
the medicine is dangerous or injurious to health, or unfit for use by human beings; or
the order is necessary to prevent or reduce a possibility of danger to public health, or to mitigate any adverse consequence of a danger to public health; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for an intermediate product—

subparagraph.content: the product is dangerous or injurious to health, or unfit for use by human beings; or
the order is necessary to prevent or reduce a possibility of danger to public health, or to mitigate any adverse consequence of a danger to public health.

section.name: s138E
section.heading: Form of Chinese medicine safety order
section.leadIn: A Chinese medicine safety order must be in the specified form and state the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person or persons intended to be bound by the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the particulars of the Chinese medicine or related product that is the subject of the order;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the reason for making the order;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the prohibition or action required under the order;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: for an order made under section 138B(1)(b), the period within which the recall is to be conducted;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the provision under which the order is made; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the consequences of failing or refusing to comply with a requirement of the order.

section.name: s138F
section.heading: Person bound by Chinese medicine safety order

subsection.leadIn: A Chinese medicine safety order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be addressed to a particular person or particular persons; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be served on each person to whom it is addressed.

subsection.content: A Chinese medicine safety order is binding on a person to whom it is addressed only from the time it is served on the person.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Variation or Revocation of Chinese Medicine Safety Order

section.name: s138G
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 3
section.content: In this Division, a reference to a Chinese medicine safety order includes a Chinese medicine safety order that is varied under section 138H(1).

section.name: s138H
section.heading: Variation of Chinese medicine safety order

subsection.content: The Director may, by order in writing, vary a Chinese medicine safety order.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under subsection (1) (variation order) must be in the specified form and state the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person or persons to whom the variation order is addressed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the order number of the Chinese medicine safety order to which the variation order relates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the reason for making the variation order;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the details of the variation;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the provision under which the variation order is made; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the consequences of failing or refusing to comply with a requirement of the Chinese medicine safety order.

subsection.content: A variation order must be addressed to and served on each person bound by the Chinese medicine safety order.
A variation order is binding on a person to whom it is addressed only from the time it is served on the person.

section.name: s138I
section.heading: Revocation of Chinese medicine safety order

subsection.content: The Director may, by order in writing, revoke a Chinese medicine safety order.

subsection.leadIn: An order made under subsection (1) (revocation order) must be in the specified form and state the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person or persons to whom the revocation order is addressed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the order number of the Chinese medicine safety order to which the revocation order relates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the reason for making the revocation order; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the provision under which the revocation order is made.

subsection.content: A revocation order must be addressed to and served on each person bound by the Chinese medicine safety order.
A revocation order has effect on a person to whom it is addressed only from the time it is served on the person.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Offence Relating to Chinese Medicine Safety Order

section.name: s138J
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 4
section.content: In this Division, a reference to a Chinese medicine safety order includes a Chinese medicine safety order that is varied under section 138H(1).

section.name: s138K
section.heading: Non-compliance is an offence
section.content: If a person bound by a Chinese medicine safety order fails or refuses to comply with a requirement of the order, the person commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged under section 138K to establish that the person had a reasonable excuse for the failure or refusal.

subsection.leadIn: The person is to be taken to have established that the person had a reasonable excuse for the failure or refusal if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that the person had such a reasonable excuse; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

part.name: P15
part.heading: Review, Appeal, Proceedings and Offences, etc.

section.name: s139
section.heading: Powers to suspend, revoke, etc. licences

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to licences—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issued under sections 114, 115, 132 and 135;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: renewed under sections 116 and 136; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: deemed to be granted under sections 118 and 138.

subsection.leadIn: The Medicines Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: suspend a licence for such period as it may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: revoke a licence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: vary the conditions or restrictions subject to which a licence was issued; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: issue a warning to the licence holder,

subsection.continued: if—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: having regard to the provisions of this Ordinance and on the recommendation of the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders, the Medicines Board considers it necessary in the public interest to do so; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.leadIn: the Medicines Board is satisfied, on the recommendation of the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders, that the licence holder—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: has failed to comply with the conditions or restrictions subject to which the licence was issued;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: has failed to comply with any prescribed conditions or duties in respect of the practice of his trade; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: has been convicted of an offence under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The suspension or revocation of a licence may be limited to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proprietary Chinese medicines of one or more descriptions;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Chinese herbal medicines of one or more descriptions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: proprietary Chinese medicines manufactured or stored in any particular premises or in a particular part of any premises; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Chinese herbal medicines stored in any particular premises or in a particular part of any premises.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of exercising its powers under this section in a particular case—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the meetings of the Medicines Board shall require a quorum of 5 members subject to at least one being a lay member;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: only members who have attended all meetings held for the purpose of that particular case may participate in the decision of the Medicines Board;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Medicines Board may invite the licence holder concerned to give representations orally or otherwise before it makes a decision.

subsection.leadIn: A member of the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders who is also a member of the Medicines Board shall not attend a meeting of the Medicines Board held for the purpose of exercising its power under this section, if that member—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has taken part in the consideration of the case when it was brought before the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is the licence holder whose licence is in question.

subsection.content: The Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders shall act in accordance with the regulations made under section 161.
The Medicines Board shall notify the licence holder concerned in writing of its decision made under this section and the reasons for the decision.

Where powers under section 114, 115, 116, 121, 123, 124, 125, 129, 132, 135 or 136 exercisable by the Medicines Board have been delegated to the Chinese Medicines Committee or the Chinese Medicines Traders Committee, as the case may be, any person aggrieved by its decision may request the Medicines Board to review the decision.
A request for review under subsection (1) shall state the reasons relied upon and shall be made to the Medicines Board within 14 days after the receipt of the notification of decision.

Upon receipt of the written request for review, the Medicines Board shall review the decision and shall serve a notice of its decision together with the reasons for its decision on the person concerned.
In reviewing a decision, the Medicines Board may invite the person concerned to give representations in writing or in person.

section.name: s141
section.heading: Right of appeal to Court of First Instance

subsection.content: A person aggrieved by any decision of the Medicines Board made under section 114, 115, 116, 121, 123, 124, 125, 129, 132, 135, 136, 139 or 140 may appeal to the Court of First Instance within 1 month from the date of service of the notice.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: A person aggrieved by a Chinese medicine safety order may appeal to the Court of First Instance against the order within 1 month from the date of service of the order on the person. (Added 16 of 2018 s. 5)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: A person aggrieved by a variation order may appeal to the Court of First Instance against the order within 1 month from the date of service of the order on the person. (Added 16 of 2018 s. 5)
The Court of First Instance may affirm, reverse or vary the decision appealed against.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Chinese medicine safety order (中藥安全令) means an order made under section 138B(1);
variation order (更改令) means an order made under section 138H(1). (Added 16 of 2018 s. 5)

section.name: s142
section.heading: Chinese herbal medicines to be labelled
section.content: A wholesale dealer in Chinese herbal medicines shall attach to or print on any container of Chinese herbal medicine a label or cause a label to be so attached or printed in the prescribed manner.

section.name: s143
section.heading: Proprietary Chinese medicines to be labelled
section.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have in his possession for the purpose of selling,

section.continued: any proprietary Chinese medicine unless the package of the proprietary Chinese medicine is labelled in the prescribed manner.

section.name: s144
section.heading: Package inserts for proprietary Chinese medicines
section.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sell; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: have in his possession for the purpose of selling,

section.continued: any proprietary Chinese medicine without a package insert which complies with the prescribed requirements.

section.name: s145
section.heading: Change of address of premises, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where there is a change in the address of the premises specified in a licence issued under this Ordinance, the licence shall become void at the expiry of 1 month from the date on which such change occurs unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for change of the address specified in the licence has been made by the licence holder to the Medicines Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prescribed fee has been paid; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Medicines Board has approved such change.

subsection.content: A licence holder shall notify the Medicines Board in writing of any change in the person or his deputies nominated in writing under section 114(2)(b) or 132(1)(b), as the case may be, within 1 month from the date of such change.
The Director may authorize in writing any public officer to be an inspector for the purpose of enforcing any provisions under this Ordinance and its regulations made under section 161.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 147, an inspector authorized under this section shall, for the purpose of enforcing the provisions under this Ordinance and its regulations, have powers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: at all reasonable times to enter and inspect any premises specified in the licence of a Chinese medicines trader where—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the wholesale or retail of any Chinese herbal medicines; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the wholesale or manufacturing of any proprietary Chinese medicines,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: upon the production of his authority as an inspector, at any time to enter and search any place and to stop, board and search any vessel, vehicle, train or aircraft (other than a ship of war, military aircraft or military vehicle) in which he has reason to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance is being or has been committed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any premises or place entered pursuant to paragraph (a) or (b), to seize, remove and detain any article, document or thing which appears to him to be or to contain evidence of an offence against this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to make such examination and inquiry and to do such other things, including the taking, on payment therefor, of samples as may be necessary for the purposes of the inspection;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to seize, remove and detain any Chinese herbal medicines specified in Schedule 1 or 2 which he has reasonable cause to suspect is in the possession of any person in contravention of section 110 or 111;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to seize, remove and detain any proprietary Chinese medicines which he has reasonable cause to suspect is in the possession of any person in contravention of section 119, 134, 143 or 144.

subsection.content: Any person who wilfully delays or obstructs an inspector in the exercise of any powers under this section, or refuses without reasonable excuse to allow any sample to be taken in accordance with this section, or fails without reasonable excuse to give any information which he is duly required under this section to give commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: If, without reasonable excuse, any person appearing to an inspector to be in charge of premises where a business of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the wholesale or retail of any Chinese herbal medicine; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the wholesale or manufacture of any proprietary Chinese medicine,

subsection.continued: is conducted, fails to disclose particulars to identify the licence holder or the owner of the business upon being required to do so by the inspector, commits an offence.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall authorize an inspector to enter or inspect the premises of a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, a listed Chinese medicine practitioner or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of section 90(7), other than those premises where the dispensing or compounding of Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines is carried on.

section.name: s147
section.heading: Power of entry and search in relation to domestic premises

subsection.leadIn: No domestic premises shall be entered or searched by an inspector unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a magistrate has issued a warrant under subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director has given an authorization under subsection (3).

subsection.content: A magistrate may, if he is satisfied by information on oath that there is reasonable ground for suspecting that there are in any domestic premises any article, document or thing which may be seized, removed or detained under section 146(2)(c), (d), (e) and (f), issue a warrant authorizing an inspector to enter and search the premises.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, if he is satisfied that there is reasonable ground for suspecting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there is in any domestic premises any article, document or thing which may be seized, removed or detained under section 146(2)(c), (d), (e) and (f); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that unless the premises are entered and searched immediately such article, document or thing is likely to be removed from the premises,

subsection.continued: authorize in writing an inspector to enter and search the premises.

subsection.content: An inspector authorized under subsection (2) or (3) to enter and search domestic premises may take with him any other person and any equipment as may appear to him to be necessary to assist him in entering and searching the premises.

No information laid in respect of any offence under this Ordinance shall be admitted in evidence and no witness in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance shall be obliged or permitted to disclose the name or address of any informer or state any matter which might lead to the discovery of the informer.

If any books, documents or papers which are in evidence or liable to inspection in any such proceedings contain any entry in which any informer is named or described or which might lead to his discovery, the court may cause all such passages to be concealed from view or to be obliterated so far as may be necessary to protect the informer from discovery.

subsection.leadIn: Where after full inquiry into the case—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the court is satisfied that the informer wilfully made in his information a material statement which he knew or believed to be false, or did not believe to be true; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it appears to the court that justice cannot otherwise fully be done,

subsection.continued: the court may require the production of the original information and permit inquiry and require full disclosure concerning the informer.

section.name: s149
section.heading: Protection of public officers
