section.content: A public officer is not personally liable for any act or omission of his if it was done or made by him in the honest belief that it was required or authorized in the exercise of any function under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Where a servant of a holder of a licence issued under this Ordinance commits an offence for contravening section 109, 110, 111, 119(1), 131, 134, 142, 143 or 144, the holder of the licence shall, without prejudice to the liability of any other person, also be guilty of that offence but shall not be liable to any term of imprisonment.

Where a prosecution is brought against a holder of a licence by virtue of this section in respect of an offence committed by a servant, it shall be a defence if the holder of the licence shows that he exercised such control over the servant as would ensure that the servant was not likely to act in contravention of the provision in question.

section.name: s151
section.heading: Commencement of proceedings
section.content: Notwithstanding any provision in any Ordinance prescribing the period within which summary proceedings may be commenced, proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance may be commenced at any time within the period of 12 months after the date of commission of the offence.

subsection.content: Any magistrate may, on application by the Government, order to be forfeited any Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines, or any article or substance with respect to which any offence relating to Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines under this Ordinance has been committed, whether or not any person has been convicted of such offence, and upon the making of any order of forfeiture, such medicines, article or substance shall be deemed to be the property of the Government free from all rights of any person.

In any proceedings on application under this section, any statement or other indication of the nature of any substance or article written upon or attached to any substance, article or container shall, until the contrary is proved, be deemed to be a true description of the substance or article or of the contents of the container, as the case may be.

For the purposes of determining an application for a licence, certificate or renewal of the same under this Ordinance, the Medicines Board may serve on the applicant a notice requiring him to furnish to it such information relating to the application and within such time as may be specified in the notice.
Where the applicant fails to furnish the information, the Medicines Board may decline to process the application further or reject the application.

No person who, in making an application to the Medicines Board or in giving any information which he is required to give under this section, shall make a statement or representations which he knows to be false or does not believe to be true in a material particular.

section.name: s154
section.heading: Disclosure of confidential information obtained officially

subsection.content: No public officer, or member of the Council, boards or committees shall, except in the circumstances set out in subsection (2), disclose or give to another person any information that concerns a trade, business or manufactory secret which has come to his knowledge or into his possession in the course of the discharge of his functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A public officer, or member of the Council, boards or committees does not contravene subsection (1) if he discloses or gives the information to another person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to discharge his functions under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under an order of a court under subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: with the consent in writing of all persons who appear to him, after reasonable inquiry, to be interested in the confidentiality of the information.

subsection.content: Where in any proceedings a court considers that the justice of the case so requires, the court may order the disclosure of information referred to in subsection (1).
Any person who contravenes section 109, 110, 111, 119(1), 131, 134, 142, 143, 144, 146(3) or (4), 153(3) or 154 commits an offence.
Any person who is found guilty of an offence under this Ordinance shall, unless a penalty is otherwise expressly provided, be liable to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for a contravention of section 110, it shall be a defence for a person charged to prove that he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: did not know;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: had no reason to suspect; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: could not with reasonable diligence have discovered,

subsection.continued: that the Chinese herbal medicine was not supplied to him in accordance with this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for a contravention of section 119(1), it shall be a defence for a person charged to prove that he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: did not know;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: had no reason to suspect; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: could not with reasonable diligence have discovered,

subsection.continued: that the proprietary Chinese medicine was not registered under section 121.

part.name: P16
part.heading: Delegations, Exemptions and Regulations, etc.

subsection.content: The boards or committees set out in column 1 of Schedule 5 may delegate all or any of their respective functions to the boards or committees set forth opposite them in columns 2 and 3 of that Schedule respectively.
The Secretary may, after consultation with the Council, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 5.

The Medicines Board may exempt, with or without conditions or restrictions, a person or institution concerned with education or scientific research from the application of sections 109(2), 110, 111(2), 119, 131 and 134 if the Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines in question are required for the purposes of education or scientific research.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in sections 109(1), 110 and 111(1) shall apply to a registered Chinese medicine practitioner if, and only if, the Chinese herbal medicines in question are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being used for the purpose of administering to a patient under his direct care; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dispensed on a prescription given by him and at the premises where he practises.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in section 110 shall apply to a person in bona fide possession of any Chinese herbal medicine specified in Schedule 1 if and only if such medicine has been supplied to him—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a person who is the holder of a licence issued under this Ordinance to trade in such Chinese herbal medicine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in accordance with a prescription given by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in accordance with this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in section 111(1) shall apply to a listed Chinese medicine practitioner or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of section 90(7) if, and only if, the Chinese herbal medicine in question is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being used for the purpose of administering to a patient under his direct care; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dispensed on a prescription given by him and at the premises where he practises.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in section 119 shall apply in respect of a proprietary Chinese medicine which is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: imported by a wholesaler in proprietary Chinese medicines for the purpose of re-exporting by the same wholesale dealer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imported by a holder of a valid certificate for clinical trial and medicinal test issued under section 129 and to be used for the purposes of the clinical trial or medicinal test to which the certificate relates.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in sections 119 and 131 shall apply in respect of a proprietary Chinese medicine which is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: compounded by or under the supervision of a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, a listed Chinese medicine practitioner or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of section 90(7) at the premises where he practises if, and only if, such proprietary Chinese medicine is being used for the purpose of administering or supplying to a patient under his direct care;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: individually prepared or compounded—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by a person nominated under section 114(2)(b)(i) or (ii); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under the supervision of such person,

paragraph.continued: at the premises in respect of which a retailer licence is in force and in accordance with a prescription given by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, a listed Chinese medicine practitioner or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of section 90(7).

subsection.content: Nothing in sections 109(2), 110, 111(2) and 134 shall apply to a person licensed under section 132 as a manufacturer of proprietary Chinese medicines if, and only if, the Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines in question are imported or obtained by the manufacturer as raw materials for the purpose of manufacturing his own products.

Nothing in section 134 shall apply to a person licensed under section 132 as a manufacturer of proprietary Chinese medicines if and only if he sells by way of wholesale the proprietary Chinese medicine manufactured by himself.

editorialNote.content: * Section 158(4) (in so far as it relates to a listed Chinese medicine practitioner) came into operation on 11 January 2008 — see L.N. 218 of 2007.

# Section 158(6) (except in relation to a proprietary Chinese medicine which is compounded by or under the supervision of a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine by virtue of section 90(7) or which is individually prepared or compounded in accordance with a prescription given by such a person) came into operation on 11 January 2008 — see L.N. 218 of 2007.

subsection.leadIn: A notice or order required to be served or given (however described) under this Ordinance may be served or given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for an individual—

subparagraph.content: by delivering it to the individual personally;
by leaving it at the individual's usual place of residence or business, or at the individual's last known address; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a company as defined by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622)—

subparagraph.content: by delivering it by hand to an officer of the company as defined by that section;

by leaving it at the company's registered office within the meaning of that Ordinance (registered office), at a place at which the company carries on business, or at the company's last known address; or
by sending it by post or registered post to the registered office, to a place at which the company carries on business, or to the company's last known address; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for a body corporate (other than a company described in paragraph (b))—

subparagraph.content: by delivering it by hand to a director, chairperson, president, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate;
by leaving it at a place at which the body corporate carries on business, or at the body corporate's last known address; or
by sending it by post or registered post to a place at which the body corporate carries on business, or to the body corporate's last known address.

subsection.content: In the absence of evidence to the contrary, a notice or order served or given under subsection (1)(a)(ii), (b)(ii) or (c)(ii) is taken as having been served or given on the day immediately following the day on which it was left at the place or address mentioned in that subsection.

In the absence of evidence to the contrary, a notice or order served or given under subsection (1)(a)(iii), (b)(iii) or (c)(iii) is taken as having been served or given on the second day after the day on which it was posted.

section.name: s160
section.heading: Fees not repayable
section.content: No refund shall be made to any person or institution of any prescribed fee or any part of any prescribed fee paid under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any fee required to be paid under this Ordinance and, in the case of fees for practising certificates issued under this Ordinance, the imposition of a surcharge for late payment of any such fee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disposal of any fee or surcharge paid or recovered under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any fee or surcharge prescribed under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be fixed at levels sufficient to effect the recovery of expenditure incurred, or likely to be incurred, by the Council, boards, committees and Government in performing their functions;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall not be limited by reason only of the amount of administrative or other costs incurred, or likely to be incurred, by the Council, boards, committees and Government in providing any service or otherwise performing any function under this Ordinance as regards any particular person or in providing any service which is of a particular class or description.

subsection.content: Regulations made under subsection (1)(a) may provide that the amount of any fee or surcharge may be fixed by reference to a scale prescribed in the regulations, and for the payment of different fees or surcharges by or in relation to different categories of Chinese medicine practitioners or persons.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may by regulation provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the duties of the Registrar;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the duties of the Council secretary; the secretaries of the Practitioners Board and the Medicines Board;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the duties of the legal advisers to the Council, boards and committees.

subsection.leadIn: With the approval of the Secretary, the Council may by regulation provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fixing of a quorum for meetings of the Council, boards and committees unless otherwise provided for under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the procedure and all such powers necessary for the purposes of and in relation to Chinese medicine practitioners regarding—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the receipt of complaints or information against a registered Chinese medicine practitioner which may be inquired into by the Practitioners Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the submission of complaints or information against a registered Chinese medicine practitioner to the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the consideration of any complaints or information against a registered Chinese medicine practitioner by the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the formulation of charges arising out of the complaints or information;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the reference of cases arising out of complaints or information to the Practitioners Board by the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: disciplinary inquiries against a registered Chinese medicine practitioner held by the Practitioners Board;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the procedure and all such powers necessary for the purposes of and in relation to Chinese herbal medicines and proprietary Chinese medicines regarding—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the receipt of complaints or information concerning a licensed Chinese medicines trader which may be considered by the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the submission of complaints or information concerning a licensed Chinese medicines trader to the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the consideration of any complaints or information concerning a licensed Chinese medicines trader by the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the submission of any complaints or information concerning a licensed Chinese medicines trader and the recommendation of the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders to the Medicines Board;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the consideration of the findings and recommendations of the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders by the Medicines Board;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the procedure and all such powers necessary for the purposes of and in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: appeals held by the Council under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: inquiries or reviews held by the Practitioners Board under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: reviews held by the Medicines Board under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: certificates, forms or other documents required for the purposes of this Ordinance, including the payment of a fee for their issue;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: the format, procedures, requirements, powers and any matter ancillary or related to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the registration of Chinese medicine practitioners;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Licensing Examination;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the issue or renewal of practising certificates; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the transitional arrangements for Chinese medicine practitioners,

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: licensing requirements in respect of an application for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: Chinese herbal medicines;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: proprietary Chinese medicines;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a retailer licence;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a manufacturer licence;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: practising conditions or duties which are applicable to the following categories of licence holder—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: Chinese herbal medicines;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: proprietary Chinese medicines;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a retailer licence;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a manufacturer licence;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: requirements regarding the experience and knowledge of a person nominated under sections 114(2)(b) and 132(1)(b);

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the period of any licence issued or renewed under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the period of any certificate issued or renewed under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: requirements regarding the form and quality of, the labelling of, and the display of distinctive marks on, containers and packages of Chinese herbal medicines or proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: requirements and conditions for the import, export, packaging, transport, storage, record-keeping, processing, acquisition, sale, dispensing and disposal of any Chinese herbal medicines;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: requirements and conditions for the import, export, packaging, transport, storage, record-keeping, acquisition, sale, manufacture and disposal of any proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: requirements for package inserts which are supplied, or are intended to be supplied, with proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: particulars to be registered for any proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.content: exempting any Chinese herbal medicines, proprietary Chinese medicines or Chinese medicines traders from the provisions of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsections (4) and (5), regulations made under those subsections may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require information, particulars and documents for the purposes of this Ordinance to be submitted and to be in such form as may be prescribed and require matters or documents for those purposes to be supported by statutory declarations or such other declarations as specified or approved by the Council;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: generally provide for the carrying into effect the provisions of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Any regulation made under this section may provide that a contravention of any provisions therein shall be an offence and may prescribe penalties for such offence not exceeding a fine at level 6 and imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s164
section.heading: Unlawful use of title etc. and practice without registration
section.leadIn: Section 28 of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161) is amended—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in subsection (3)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in paragraph (f), by repealing “and”;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in paragraph (g), by repealing the full stop and substituting “; and”;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: by adding—

paragraph.content: by way of practising Chinese medicine by a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549) or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine provisionally by virtue of section 90(7) of that Ordinance.”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by adding—

subsection.content: Without prejudice to any Ordinance relating to the prosecution of criminal offences or to the powers of the Secretary for Justice in relation to the prosecution of criminal offences, prosecutions for an offence in connection with the practice of Chinese medicine shall only be brought under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549).”.

editorialNote.content: * Section 164(a)(iii) (but only to the extent that new section 28(3)(h) of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161) relates to a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549)) came into operation on 1 March 2002 — see L.N. 6 of 2002.

section.name: s165
section.heading: Section substituted
section.content: Section 31 is repealed and the following substituted—

subsection.content: Nothing in this Ordinance shall be deemed to affect the right of any Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549) or any person who continues to practise Chinese medicine provisionally by virtue of section 90(7) of that Ordinance, not being a person taking or using any name, title, addition or description calculated to induce anyone to believe that he is qualified to practise medicine or surgery under this Ordinance, to practise Chinese medicine in accordance with the provisions of that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.content: the taking or using in Chinese by any person of the name, title, addition or description of “西醫”, “醫生”, “醫師”, “醫士”, “醫學士”, “醫學博士”, “男醫”, “女醫”, “醫科”, “醫家”, “醫寓”, “醫院”, “醫務院”, “醫所”, “醫務所”, “醫療所”, “診療所”, “療病院”, and the taking or using of any words or characters implying specialization if preceded by or used in combination with words or characters other than “中” or “中醫” shall be deemed to be the taking or using of a name, title, addition or description calculated to induce anyone to believe that he is qualified to practise medicine or surgery under this Ordinance and that he is registered under this Ordinance;

the taking or using in Chinese by a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549) or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine provisionally by virtue of section 90(7) of that Ordinance of the name, title, addition or description of “醫生”, “醫師”, “醫士”, “醫學士”, “醫學博士”, “男醫”, “女醫”, “醫科”, “醫家”, “醫寓”, “醫院”, “醫務院”, “醫所”, “醫務所”, “醫療所”, “診療所”, “療病院” or any words or characters implying specialization, when preceded by or used in combination with the character “中” or characters “中醫”, shall not be deemed to be the taking or using of a name, title, addition or description calculated to induce anyone to believe that he is qualified to practise medicine or surgery under this Ordinance or that he is registered under this Ordinance.”.

editorialNote.content: Section 165 (but only to the extent that new section 31 of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161) relates to any Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549)) came into operation on 1 March 2002 — see L.N. 6 of 2002.

section.name: s168
section.heading: Certain defences; provision as to Chinese medicine practitioners
section.leadIn: Section 5 is amended—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by repealing subsection (1)(d) and substituting—

Chinese medicine practitioners registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549) or persons who continue to practise Chinese medicine provisionally by virtue of section 90(7) of that Ordinance.”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in subsection (2), by repealing “native herbalist” and substituting “Chinese medicine practitioner”.

editorialNote.content: * Section 168(a) (but only to the extent that new section 5(1)(d) of the Undesirable Medical Advertisements Ordinance (Cap. 231) relates to Chinese medicine practitioners registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549)) came into operation on 1 March 2002 — see L.N. 6 of 2002.

section.name: s170
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: Section 2 of the Medical Clinics Ordinance (Cap. 343) is amended—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the definition of “clinic”, by repealing paragraph (f) and substituting—

premises used exclusively by a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549) or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine provisionally by virtue of section 90(7) of that Ordinance in the course of his practice;”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the definition of “medical treatment”, by repealing paragraphs (c) and (d) and substituting—
the dispensation of Chinese herbal medicines under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549);

the treatment given by a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549) or a person who continues to practise Chinese medicine provisionally by virtue of section 90(7) of that Ordinance;”.

editorialNote.content: * Section 170(a) (but only to the extent that new paragraph (f) of the definition of “clinic” in section 2 of the Medical Clinics Ordinance (Cap. 343) relates to a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap.549)) came into operation on 1 March 2002 — see L.N. 6 of 2002.

# Section 170(b) (in respect of new paragraph (c) of the definition of “medical treatment” in section 2 of the Medical Clinics Ordinance (Cap. 343), and new paragraph (d) of that definition but only to the extent it relates to a Chinese medicine practitioner registered or listed under the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549)) came into operation on 1 March 2002 — see L.N. 6 of 2002.

part.name: PI
part.heading: Functions of the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board
part.leadIn: The functions of the Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to implement the policy and activities as determined by the Council, and to provide guidance to its committees;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make recommendations and reports to the Council regarding its activities or the implementation of policies;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to approve or reject applications for registration, limited registration and restoration to the Register;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to set and conduct the Licensing Examination;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to determine the requirements in respect of continuing education in Chinese medicine;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to direct the Registrar to make any alterations to the Register;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to inquire into the conduct of applicants for registration as Chinese medicine practitioners and to conduct inquiry proceedings in respect of the conduct and discipline of registered Chinese medicine practitioners and where appropriate, to make such orders as provided for under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: h
i
paragraph.content: to conduct reviews, where appropriate, against decisions of the committees as provided for under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under the Ordinance or delegated to it by the Council.

part.name: PII
part.heading: Functions of the Chinese Medicines Board
part.leadIn: The functions of the Chinese Medicines Board shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to implement the policy and activities as determined by the Council, and to provide guidance to its committees;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make recommendations and reports to the Council regarding its activities or the implementation of policies;

paragraph.name: c
d
e
paragraph.content: to advise the Council on any amendments to Schedules 1 and 2;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to inquire into the conduct of licensed traders of Chinese medicines and to determine the action to be taken against a licensed trader;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to issue relevant certificates under the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to implement the transitional arrangements for licensing of traders of Chinese medicines and registration of proprietary Chinese medicines;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to handle reviews against decisions of the committees as provided for under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under the Ordinance or delegated to it by the Council.

part.name: PI
part.heading: Functions of the Registration Committee
part.leadIn: The functions of the Registration Committee shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Practitioners Board on the qualifications for registration of Chinese medicine practitioners;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to and assist the Practitioners Board on the procedure, documentation and forms for registration of Chinese medicine practitioners;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to assist the Practitioners Board to consider any application for registration as Chinese medicine practitioners;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Practitioners Board on matters relating to the requirements in respect of continuing education in Chinese medicine; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under the Ordinance or delegated to it by the Practitioners Board.

part.name: PII
part.heading: Functions of the Examination Committee
part.leadIn: The functions of the Examination Committee shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Practitioners Board on the qualifications or training required before a person is considered eligible to undertake the Licensing Examination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under the Ordinance or delegated to it by the Practitioners Board.

part.name: PIII
part.heading:
Functions of the Disciplinary Committee of
Chinese Medicine Practitioners
part.leadIn: The functions of the Disciplinary Committee of Chinese Medicine Practitioners shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to conduct preliminary investigation into any complaint or information received relating to the professional conduct of any registered Chinese medicine practitioner or applicant for registration which may be inquired into by the Practitioners Board; and to give advice on such matters to the Practitioners Board; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Practitioners Board for the holding of an inquiry.

part.name: PIV
part.heading: Functions of the Chinese Medicines Committee
part.leadIn: The functions of the Chinese Medicines Committee shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Medicines Board on any amendments to Schedules 1 and 2;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under the Ordinance or delegated to it by the Chinese Medicines Board.

part.name: PV
part.heading: Functions of the Chinese Medicines Traders Committee
part.leadIn: The functions of the Chinese Medicines Traders Committee shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Medicines Board on the licensing requirements, practising conditions and guidelines in respect of different categories of Chinese medicines traders required to be licensed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to carry out any other functions assigned to it under the Ordinance or delegated to it by the Medicines Board.

part.name: PVI
part.heading:
Functions of the Regulatory Committee of
Chinese Medicines Traders
part.leadIn: The functions of the Regulatory Committee of Chinese Medicines Traders shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to conduct investigation into any complaint or information received relating to the conduct of a licensed Chinese medicines trader which may be inquired into by the Medicines Board; and where it considers appropriate, to give advice on the matter to the Chinese medicines trader concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make recommendations to the Medicines Board as to the appropriate course of action to be taken against the Chinese medicines trader concerned.

td.p: Chinese Medicine Practitioners Board to set and conduct Licensing Examination (section 59)
Service of notice and order of removal from Register (section 57)
Provisions relating to renewal of limited registration (section 89)
List maintained by Practitioners Board (section 90(1), (2), (3)(a), (4) and (5))
Licensing of retailer in Chinese herbal medicines (section 114)
Licensing of wholesale dealers in Chinese herbal medicines (section 115)
Licensing of wholesale dealers in proprietary Chinese medicines (section 135)
Duration and renewal of certificate of registration (section 123)
Variation of registered particulars of registered proprietary Chinese medicines (section 124)
Certificate of sale of proprietary Chinese medicines (section 130)
